For  a change in the  rules the  MSMA had  to  be 
unanimous, and  it took until the  Silverstone meeting 
at the  end  of May for the  Italian manufacturers (mainly 
Aprilia) to  line  up with the  four Japanese factories. 
Thus the  FIM  was able to announce that the  Superbike 
Commission (consisting of Claude Danis of the  FIM, 
Paolo Flammini of SBK International, an  MSMA 
representative and  a  representative of the  teams) had 
approved new regulations for the  2003 championship 
designed to get those 1000cc fours in. 
Previous suggestions about treaded tyres were 
quietly forgotten and  the  announcement was brief 
and  to  the  point: 1000cc fours would be allowed in 
under current regulations but  with a  minimum weight 
of  168kg and  with air  restricters. The restricters would 
be 26.3mm in diameter for a single intake and 18.7mm 
if the  bike had  two. The  idea of this  sort  of regulation 
was  to  level the  playing field for  privateers by effectively 
power-capping motors. If you  can  only flow so  much air 
you  can  only make so  much power no  matter what you 
do.  Theoretically, this  was much easier to  police than 
the  Supersport regulations, and severely limited engine 
tuning. Most people were agreed that this  was a  pretty 
good compromise, although some asked what the 
point was of building £20,000 motors and  then 
strangling them. 
Meanwhile the  show went on  with the  old  rules and 
one Honda up  against the  same Ducati teams as  last 
year —  Bayliss and  Xaus in the  Corse team, Hodgson and 
Toseland in the  HM  Plant squad and Ben Bostrom in the 
L&M team. Noriyuki Haga returned after a  disgruntled 
year In  GPs  to  pilot the  lone Aprilia, Kawasaki brought 
in  2000 Sugo double winner Hitoyasu |zutsu and, to 
the  delight of British fans, Chris Walker —  who'd had  an 
even worse 2001 in GPs  than Haga. Gregorio Lavilla left 
Kawasaki to  replace Chili on  the  Suzuki while the  Italian 

found himself on  a  private NCR Ducati. 
Tyres might not  have played a  part in  the  new 
regulations but  they did  in  the  racing. Michelin had 
spent a lot of time and effort developing a  fresh 
generation of S4 slicks to  cope with the  new MotoGP 
four-strokes. Happily they also worked on  Superbikes, 
to  the  tune of around a  second a  lap improvement 
Unhappily, Dunlop hadn't made a similarly great leap 
forward and  Messrs Hodgson, Bostrom and  Haga found 
themselves at an  acute disadvantage at  most tracks —  as 
did  the  Michelin runners who didn’t have access to  the 
new rubber. 
For  this  and  other reasons the  championship 
quickly became a two-man race between riders with 
S4  Michelins: reigning champ Troy Bayliss and his 
predecessor Colin Edwards. Dunlop's qualifiers were, as 
usual, on  the  pace for the  one-lap dash of Superpole 
which let  Hodgson, Bostrom and Haga fight for front- 
row  starts but  rarely for the  win. The  first  three rounds 
of the  year were a  Bayliss benefit. He  won every race, 
something no-one had  done before at the  start of 
the  year —  but,  just as  he was eyeing up  Doug Polen’s 
record of seven races on  the  trot, the  circus came to 
Sugo, the  track where Bayliss had  crashed twice in 
2000 and  scored a  grand total of four points in 2001. 
Not  surprisingly, the  benefit came to  an  end. Very 
surprisingly, a Michelin rider won a  race in Japan for the 
first  time since Takuma Aoki in  ‘96.  That man was Colin 
Edwards, the  Texan sharing the  wins with local Honda 
man and  All-Japan Champion Makoto Tamada. It was 
also the  first Sugo win by a  non-Japanese rider since 
'95. Bayliss wasn’t fazed by missing out  on  the  record 
for consecutive wins, and instead seemed happy to 
escape from his  bogey track with fifth and  fourth places. 
Sugo also gave the  World Superbike paddock its first 
sight of Ben Bostrom’s brother Eric  away from his  home 
round. Eric, Kawasaki's AMA Superbike star, was  taking

There were more departures from the  form book at 
Laguna Seca: Bayliss and Edwards scored their maiden 
wins there but, more significantly, the  first race rostrum 
was 100  per  cent Michelin. Local wild cards Bostrom the 
Younger and Nicky Hayden mixed it up with the  regulars 
with Eric  actually leading the  race for  a  while and 
scoring a  sixth and  a fourth. Hayden had  been expected 
to  compete for a win but  instead took a fighting fourth 
in  Race 1, then crashed and  took Haga out  in Race 2 
before getting back on  to  finish 13th. Both Americans 
were obviously well worth tempting away from the 
domestic scene —  but  could anyone afford to  match the 
wages they got  in AMA racing? 
Bayliss now led  the  championship by 53  points, 
despite the  fact that Colin Edwards was riding as  well as, 
if not  better than, he  had  ever done and  only been off 
the  rostrum once —  yes,  once —  all season. The  reigning 
champ was riding at the  top  of his form. He  looked just 
as  fast  and loose as  ever and the  number-one plate had 
certainly done nothing to  reduce his  will  to  win  —  and 
that, combined with the  latest Ducati, gave him the 
slightest of advantages over Edwards. Troy ruthlessly 
exploited that edge, but  the  Honda rider never gave up 
50  much as a single point without a fight. Edwards was 
mentally tough enough to  keep the  pressure up,  and 
every time Troy stood on  top  of the  rostrum there was 
Colin beside him. 
Of the  Dunlop runners it was Neil Hodgson who 
was emerging as  the  toughest, comfortably outgunning 
the  disappointing Haga and the  patchy Bostrom. His 
motivation was helped by Ducati announcing he would 
be  in the  full  works Ducati Corse team for  2003 to 
replace Bayliss who, it was assumed, would go  off 
to  Ducati’s new MotoGP project. The form of Ruben 
Xaus was a  mystery, but  it emerged late  in  the  season 
that he had  not  had  access to  the  latest Michelins 
until half-way through the  year. Chris Walker was 
pleasing his  hard-core fans by usually, although by no 
means always, winning the  four-cylinder 750cc battle 
with Lavilla. Young British hopeful James Toseland 
continued on  his  learning curve and  added steel to  his 
skill, as  a spectacular last-corner mugging of Haga at 
Oschersleben showed. His  emotional rostrum finish in 

Race 2 at  Assen was well deserved. Young Aussie Broc 
Parkes on a Pirelli-shod Ducati also showed promise, as 
you would expect from a  protégé of Wayne Gardner 
As  the  mid-season break approached the  question 
on  everyone's lips was, could anyone beat Bayliss and 
would he  trump Doug Polen’s record of  17  wins in  a 
season? Ironically, the  person who nearly cost Bayliss 
his  championship lead was his  team-mate, Ruben 
Xaus. It happened at  Brands Hatch on  the  out-lap of 
a  qualifying session. Both Ducati Corse riders were 
on  the  way up  the  hill  to  Druids hairpin early in  the 
lap,  Xaus weaving to  get  some heat into his  tyres as 
Bayliss came up  considerably faster on  the  outside 
Ruben didn’t know his  team-mate was coming and 
moved to  the  left  as  Troy was overtaking, with the 
result that Bayliss was sent onto the  grass where he 
fell  and scraped along the  Armco barrier. It was a 
messy crash and the  Aussie was obviously hurt. He 
was still  suffering from a  sore back thanks to  a  crash 
in  qualifying at  Laguna and this  incident aggravated it 
and added a  broken rib  for  good measure 
Under the  circumstances his  third and second places 
at  Brands were heroic, but  Edwards did  the  double for 
the  first time in the  season and took a big bite  out  of 
the  gap at  the  top  of the  championship. From Bayliss’s 
World Superbikes: The First 20  Years 155 



point of view, the  silver lining was the  four-week break 
in  the  calendar before Oschersleben that enabled him  to 
get  back to  full  fitness. 
The other seismic event at  Brands was the  first public 
outing of the  Foggy Petronas bike in  the  hands of team 
riders Troy Corser and James Haydon, as  well as  a  couple 
of laps from King Carl himself. The  bikes had  actually 
been unveiled in  June amid assurances that the  target 
of racing at  Laguna Seca was attainable. That date was 
then amended to  Brands before the  team had  to  admit 
defeat and postpone the  FP1's race debut until 2003. 
Producing enough road bikes for  homologation was 
the  main stumbling block and  the  MSMA was in no 
mood to  show the  leniency they'd exhibited to  Benelli. 
Typically, Carl brushed aside his earlier statements about 
how he’d make people eat  their words when his team 
met  the  deadline by reflecting that perhaps this  pressure 
was necessary to  drive the  project forward. He  probably 
had  a  point. The  bike certainly showed some very nice 
detailing, and  with Petronas bankrolling things there was 
no  shortage of money —  but  the  team now had  to  revise 
their 900cc triple to  compete not  just with the  V-twins 
but with 1000cc four-cylinder bikes. 
The  Oschersleben round saw Edwards close the  gap 
even more, with another double, making it five  wins on 
the  trot. He  also passed a few  significant milestones. 
Race 1 gave the  Castrol Honda team their 50th World 
Superbike win  and Race 2 took Colin to joint second in 
the  all-time winners’ table alongside Doug Polen. It was 
also the  100th win  by an  American rider and  equalled 
Polen’s record of 21  podiums in a year, though Colin had 
scored them consecutively. Even Foggy in his  pomp had 
only managed a  dozen consecutive top-three finishes, in 
1995. All that work and  Edwards was still  second in  the 
title race! 
Bayliss’s Brands crash had  obscured the  fact  that 
Honda had  supplied Edwards with a  new motor after 
the  Suzuka 8 Hour race, where Colin was teamed with 
Daijiro Kato and  won. The  Texan was on a roll,  and 
all of  a sudden Bayliss was looking vulnerable with his 
championship lead after Germany reduced to  29  points. 
As  so  often, Assen was the  turning point. Race 1 
featured the  two main men again, with Bayliss following 
Edwards home. That reduced the  lead to  24  points, 
and with only three more races on  the  calendar Troy 
could afford that rate  of attrition. But  the  Aussie was 
feeling the  strain and, according to  other riders, making 
unforced errors. In  Race 2 he  made several. The  first  was 
to  run  off track, but  he stayed on  his wheels and  set 
about reeling in the  third-place dice between Hodgson 
and Haga. When Nori punted Neil into the  sand Bayliss 
inherited a safe third place. Inexplicably, he then crashed 
a couple of laps from the  flag and Colin won again to 
equal Polen’s record run  of seven consecutive victories. 
When Edwards got the  pit signal telling him  that his  rival 
was out  he couldn't quite believe it and ‘used up  a year’s 
worth of concentration’ getting to  the  flag. Much more 
importantly, he also went to  the  top  of the  table, the 
first  time Troy Bayliss had  been deposed all  season. The 
lead? One solitary point, with only the  Imola round left

It was a  fitting finale. The two contenders, the  men 
who had  so  far won all  but  one  of the  races in  the  year, 
went at  it like  a  six-lap club race. The lap record was 
shredded time after time, and  to  add to  the  drama Race 
1 was interrupted by a  red  flag half-way through when 
Edwards was leading. Conspiracy theorists pointed to 
the  fact that the  flag  came out  very quickly, just  as 
the  Italian Ducati appeared to  be  losing touch with 
the  Honda. In  truth, it worked to  Edwards's advantage 
as  he  knew he  had  a 0.7s lead and  thus was able to 
follow Bayliss across the  line  after the  restart yet win  on 
corrected time to  give him a  six-point lead with only one 
race left. 
The  last  race of the  season was a real  classic. Bayliss, 
as  usual, gave it everything while Edwards refused to 
yield up  the  victory. Despite the  fact the  title  was at 
stake the  last  lap involved fairing-bashing and several 
changes of lead. Fittingly, the  American took the  win 
and the  title while Bayliss appeared on  the  surface to 
be a  lot  less  upset than he’d been after Assen, maybe 
because it had  been a fair  fight and he'd simply been 
beaten on  the  day. 
In 2002 both men had  ridden better than they ever 
had  before. Bayliss lost  none of his aggression and 
frightening will  to win  despite carrying the  number-one 
plate, while Edwards refused to  be discouraged by the 
Aussie’s runaway start to the  year and  maintained his 
motivation. He  also  showed, notably at  Imola, that he 
could mix  it with the  best of them. There was  huge 
pressure on  Troy Bayliss, not  least because the  showdown 
was at  Ducati’s home track. Well, the  last  race wasn't a 
fight, it was a war  —  and  Colin Edwards won. 
The  other man who didn’t lose his  motivation was 
Neil Hodgson who emerged as  clearly the  fastest of the 
Dunlop runners and, as  his third place overall showed, 
he firmly put a  few Michelin men in their place too. 
Knowing that he would be  a  Ducati factory rider in 
2003 must have contributed to  his  motivation in  the 
final race. 
The  statistics tell  the  story of the  season. The  year 
was dominated by just two men —  the  only other winner 
all year was Tamada at  Sugo. In the  first half  of the 
year Troy Bayliss was supreme, but  the  only time Colin 
Edwards was  off the  rostrum was in the  first  race of 
the  year. Once Bayliss had  suffered that unfortunate 
injury at  Brands, Edwards and  his  new motor took over 
and  shattered the  all-time records for consecutive wins, 
consecutive rostrums and number of rostrums in a 
season. Anyone who wants to  beat those last  two marks 
is  going to  have to finish in  the  top three in every race of 
a  season! In the  final analysis, Edwards had  as  near an 
error-free season as  it's  possible to  imagine. Bayliss made 
one mistake. That was the  difference between them.

he 2003 season was a real  Ducati-fest, with the 
Bologna Bullets winning all  24  races —  albeit with five 
different riders. Although the  Michelin-shod full  factory 
bikes of Neil Hodgson and Ruben Xaus dominated from 
the  outset, Dunlop did  manage to  get  in  on  the  act  with 
James Toseland, Pierfrancesco Chili and  wild card Shane 
Byrne, but  the  war was very much won by their French 
competitors. Ducati’s domination was such that they 
took 64  of the  available 72  podium places, leaving many 
media observers (and fans) to  regard the  season as  more 
of a  Ducati Cup than a World Championship. 
A change of rules after 2002 and  the  continuing spat 
between the  MSMA and FGSport were the  reason for 
the  Ducati domination. For  2003, the  four-cylinder bikes 
could be  up  to  1000cc in  capacity but  had  to  be fitted 
with restricters. It had been pretty clear the  750cc fours 
had been struggling to  match the  998cc Ducatis for 
some time, and half-way through 2002 an  agreement 
was reached between the  FIM, MSMA and FGSport to 
allow 1000cc bikes to  compete next season. But  the 
adoption of restricters was not  greeted with universal 
enthusiasm, the  question ‘Why design, develop and 
spend a lot  of money building a  new race bike and  then 
Strangle it?’  being asked many times. In  the  end, the 
2003 season started with only one really competitive 
four-cylinder 1000cc bike (a  factory-supported Suzuki) 
but  its  comparative lack of success meant it would not 
continue into 2004 
Many viewed 2003 as  an  ‘interim year’, but 
that should not  detract from the  single-minded 
determination of its  champion, Briton Neil Hodgson

was always fast  and consistent when it mattered —  on 
race day. Xaus took longer to  master the  new 999 F03 
Ducati, but  ended the  season very strongly with four 
wins out  of the  last  six  races. If he’d started better, 
maybe Hodgson's task would have been harder, but  in 
the  end  the  Spanish rider finished in second place, some 
103  points behind Neil’s winning tally of 489. 
The  Suzuki GSX-R1000 prepared by the  Belgian 
Alstare team and piloted by Spaniard Gregorio Lavilla 
was an  occasional threat to  the  booming twins but, 
although he took seven podiums, a win  eluded him. 
Honda, Kawasaki and  Yamaha chose not  to  lend their 
support to  any  team, preferring to  observe proceedings, 
but  there was one completely new manufacturer present 
—  Petronas. The  Malaysian company bankrolled their 
own 900cc triple —  a  project that should have been 
on  the  track in 2002 —  and  were fronted by four-times 
champ Carl Fogarty. Petronas were without doubt the 
largest presence in the  paddock and looked to  be well 
prepared, marshalled by former Team Roberts crewman: 
Nigel Bosworth. But, having designed and built from 
scratch a  900cc bike before the  rule  change, how much 
of a disadvantage would they face because of their 
lesser cubic capacity? Certainly, on  paper, they had 
one of the  strongest line-ups: former World Superbike 
Champion Troy Corser and  the  experienced 29-year-old 
Briton, James Haydon. Time would tell  if the  package 
would be good enough. 
Team GSE Racing, sponsored by HM  Plant, were on 
the  2002 ex-Bayliss spec bikes and  were the  only team, 
apart from the  Fila  Ducatis, on  Michelins. Toseland 
and  Chris Walker flew the  flag for the  small but  well- 
organised British team and between them took one 
win  and 14  podiums. Veteran Chili was riding for Team 
PSG-1, sporting a  distinctly non-Ducati bright yellow 
colour scheme, but  the  bikes were two years old  and 
although he scored a  remarkable victory in  the  USA, 
the  rest  of his season was littered with non-finishes

At the  start of the  season three different tyre 
companies were involved in the  championship, but 
maybe only one had  an  inkling of how that would 
change before the  year’s end! 
Round 1 saw  the  race debut of the  Ducati 999  —  an 
important bike for the  Italian manufacturer. After the 
beauty and  originality of its 916  Ducati knew a  change 
had  to  come, but  the  999  wasn't initially viewed with 
the  same excitement —  and certainly not  in  road livery. 
The  race bike, though, was built to  take the  title and 
for  Ducati that’s what mattered. It hadn't been long in 
development and most of its  track time had  been spent 
at Valencia, which was just as  well: Hodgson swept to 
two comfortable wins at the  Ricardo Tormo circuit, with 
Fila  team-mate Xaus taking an  even more comfortable 
pair  of seconds. Hodgson’s effort was ballsy to  say 
the  least —  unknown to  most, the  Briton was taking 
painkilling injections to  relieve the  discomfort of crash- 
damaged ribs  the  week before. The new 999s were 
also giving both riders front-end problems, particularly 
entering turns and  on  the  brakes. Despite this, the

factory Dukes were in a  class of their own, with HM 
Plant's duo, Walker and Toseland, taking a third apiece 
ahead of the  remaining Ducatis, already starting to  look 
well past their sell-by date, and  Lavilla’s restricted Suzuki, 
which managed a forlorn seventh in  Race 1 and  sixth in 
Race 2, both times the  first non-Ducati finisher. If there 
was any  consolation for  Gregorio’s team it was that 
the  all-new Petronas had  fared worse. All  they could 
muster was one  finish in each race, 12th by Haydon in 
Race 1 and  seventh by Corser in  Race 2 —  particularly 
disappointing as  Troy had  been in  the  top  four in  both 
regular and Superpole qualifying. 
Before the  season started, Valencia had  been seen 
by some as  the  dawning of a  new era  for  1000cc four- 
cylinder race bikes, but  Lavilla’s Suzuki was the  sole 
strong entry and his team left  Spain knowing that it was 
going to  be a  long, hard season ahead. 
The  second round, in Australia, gave the  Belgian- 
based outfit some hope, because Lavilla took a 
tremendous third place on  his  Dunlop-shod GSX-R 
in the  opening race. The team had done masses of 
work on  the  engine, trying to  regain some of the 
power lost  because of the  restricters, and they got 
their reward at  one  of the  fastest and  best-loved 
tracks of the  year. Phillip Island is  a  real ‘riders’ track’, 
full  of fast  sweepers and long straights requiring a 
completely full-on approach —  and  fans love it too, for 
no  matter the  conditions the  racing is  always good, 
though unpredictable. Although Lavilla was the  ‘man 
of the  meeting’ for  giving a  1000cc four-cylinder bike 

its  maiden podium, it was Hodgson who controlled 
proceedings with another double. His  victory margin 
in  Race 1 was over seven seconds, but  ne  really had 
to  work for  win number two, beating Xaus again, but 
this  time by just 0.070s thanks to  clever tactics and the 
ability to  squeeze behind the  999’s fairing better than 
his  lankier rival. If Xaus had not  suffered three practice 
crashes (including one on  his  Superpole lap) and had to 
Start on  the  second row of the  grid, perhaps it would 
have been a  different story. The home star  was Corser, 
who once again started from the  front row, taking 
a superb fifth in  the  first race followed by eighth in 
Race 2, perhaps a fairer indication of his  FP1’s ability. 
Fellow-countryman Martin gave his  Pirelli-shod 998 
RS  its  best finish of the  year, a  fourth in  Race 1, while 
Chili just  failed to  take Superpole (that honour, and the 
accompanying Breil watch, went to  Hodgson) and then 
DNFd. That fired the  Italian up,  at  one of his  favourite 
tracks, and he stormed through to  third place in  the 
second 22-lapper, the  sixth different rider on  the  podium 
in just four races. Maybe the  season wouldn't be  so 
predictable after all, although who would realistically 
be able to  stop Hodgson’s relentless pursuit of the  title? 
With just four races gone he  had a perfect tally of  100 
points. Second-placed Xaus, however, was only 20 
points adrift and  there was a  long way to  go. 
Sugo has  never been a  happy hunting ground for 
‘foreign’ riders, at  least until Edwards equalled Tamada 
for  maximum points in  2002. The  local wild-card riders 
were on  Dunlops, developed in Japan, while Michelin 
had little or  no  presence on  the  Japanese race scene, 
so  it was a  bit of a surprise that Hodgson took his third 
double of the  season to  maintain his  perfect score. He'd 
struggled in  qualifying and  only managed the  fifth- 
quickest time behind four Dunlop-shod riders —  Laconi, 
Chili, Lavilla and  local hotshot Atsushi Watanabe. Laconi 
posed the  biggest threat to  Hodgson in  Race 1, but  Neil 
was able to  clear off  in the  last  few laps and  took the 
chequered flag with an  easy-looking margin of seven 
seconds. The race had  begun dramatically, with Toseland 
and Corser unwilling participants in  a  chain of events 
that led  to  four riders being put  out  before they had 
made the  first turn. The mechanical and human debris 
caused havoc, though fortunately there were no  serious 
njuries, but  the  pattern of the  race (minus fallers Chili, 
Walker, Corser and Clementi) was immediately affected 
Toseland managed to  avoid going down and  then 
ought his  way up  to  a  gritty third place by the  end of 
the  25-lap race to  make it three different generations of 
Ducatis in  the  top  three. Xaus battled to  fourth, despite 
set-up problems, incorrect tyre choice and having to

way out  of turns as  well. Chili made up  for  his  fall  in  the 
first race by taking third, with Xaus again posting fourth

No  Superbike rider had  ever won eight races in a 
row before Monza, but  Hodgson squeaked a victory in 
the  first race to  give the  Bologna marque its 200th win 
—a   fitting touch in their home country and  at one  of 
the  most revered tracks in the  world —  and  then went 
on  to win Race 2, and  all after setting new records 
in qualifying and  Superpole. Neil may have ridden his 
luck in the  18-lap opener, after seeing a three-second 
lead shrink to just 0.352s at the  flag. The pursuer who 
nearly spoilt his  party was Laconi; if the  flag had been 
further down the  track Ducati would still  have notched 
up win number 200, but  the  Briton would've lost  his 
perfect sequence. Third place went to  Lavilla and the 
increasingly competitive Suzuki, leading many to  think 
that a win  was surely ‘when’ rather than ‘if’.  The  second 
race was a Classic Monza multi-rider slipstreaming 
battle, with Hodgson, Chili, Lavilla and  Laconi all  in 
with a  chance of victory, to  entertain the  72,000-strong 
crowd. Leaving the  Ascari for the  final time, however, 
the  factory grunt of Hodgson’s Ducati was enough to 
clinch top  spot, though the  margin of 0.044s over the 
Suzuki was the  closest so  far.  Chili took third, much to 
the  delight of his  home fans, with Laconi fourth. It was 
not  a good day for the  other title  contender, with Ascari 
the  scene of Xaus’s problems on  both occasions. In 
Race 1 he tangled with Walker and  went off the  track, 
restarted in last  place, then charged back up  to  seventh. 

In  Race 2 he  made a  mistake and  crashed, but  this  time 
was unable to  restart. Ruben left  Monza bruised and 
battered, still  second in the  championship but  now just 
four points ahead of Lavilla. 
Oschersleben was a real  Brit-fest, with five  out  of six 
podium places taken by British riders. Only Chili, on  his 
aged customer Ducati, spoiled the  symmetry of the  first 
rostrum. He  almost halted Hodgson’s run  of victories 
too, but  Neils last-corner move was astute enough 
to  secure his  ninth win  of the  year. Toseland was 
pushed off track by the  crashing Lavilla at the  first  turn, 
thundered across the  run-off area and  was lucky not  to 
cause a  multiple pile-up with the  leaders as  he  rejoined. 
By the  time he sorted himself out  he was dead last. 
James then fought his way through the  field to finish 
an  aggressive third, but  better was to  come in Race 2. 
Hodgson and  Toseland led  the  pack and clattered into 
each other with sufficient force to temporarily dislodge 
Neil's clutch lever and redesign some of the  Fila  Ducati’s 
paintwork. Both riders called the  incident ‘an  accident’; 
the  fans loved it. Toseland’s maiden World Superbike 
win  saw not  only the  first-ever all-British podium but 
was also significant for  Dunlop, recording their first 
victory since Sugo in 2002. 
Silverstone in June was as  June should be —  warm 
and  sunny. A crowd of 83,000 was rewarded by two 
superbly entertaining races, with British riders prominent 
both, but  everyone agreed the  final chicane was a 
saster. Chicanes are  a  necessary nuisance but  the 
lverstone effort, comprising a  stupid mid-apex bump 
nd  obtuse left-right design attracted criticism from all 
uarters. However, it did  serve some purpose, causing 
close ten-rider pack to  bunch up  on  almost every lap 
the  first race. It was a  particularly important round 
for  Lavilla. Machine improvements after the  start of 
the  season had  given him  the  scent of victory, and 
Silverstone was  just  the  kind of track where the  Suzuki 
could get the  better of Hodgson’s Ducati. Gregorio, 
though, hadn't reckoned on  Neil’s self-belief and 
determination not  to  be  beaten by a  four-cylinder bike. 
There were also two other strong GSX-R1000s in  the 
shape of British Superbike contenders John Reynolds and 
Yukio Kagayama. 
Race 1 featured a five-rider freight train, all  in  with 
chance, but  Hodgson kept his  nerve and showed his 
aggression, a  testament to  his  improvement since 2002: 
when it mattered he delivered the  goods and  took the 
win, his tenth of the  season, with Toseland second, Xaus 
third and  Japanese rider and British crowd favourite 
Kagayama providing further entertainment. Race 2 was 
no  less  of a  battle: Lavilla had  been in  contention in  the 
first race until a fall  at the  final chicane, now he was a 
genuine challenger. Lap after lap the  duo slugged it out 
but, at  the  flag, Hodgson had  just enough left  to take

| knew that Lavilla could do well at Silverstone, so  | 
was more than determined not  to  let  him  beat me.  | 
would've done anything not  to  let him  win  because he’d 
have grown in confidence so  much and  | didn’t want 
that to  happen.’ 
Once again Misano’s high temperatures and humidity 
made life difficult for everyone, but  maybe it was  the 
heat of the  moment that caused Hodgson to  crash 
uncharacteristically on  lap one  of the  first race and  leave 
the  battle to Xaus and  Toseland. Ruben had  started 
from row  three, but  made a  mockery of his grid place 
by storming up the  inside of most of his competitors 
—  usually at the  series of long left-handers leading onto 
the  back straight. Toseland held off  Laconi for second 
place, with Lavilla’s Suzuki some way back in fourth 
despite suffering the  effects of a  hard fall  in qualifying. 
Xaus won Race 2 as  well, beating Hodgson in a  hard- 
fought battle, neither rider giving way throughout the 
25-lapper. The  ever-popular Chili took third, ahead of 
Lacon! and  Lavilla, who was almost embarrassed by 
former Superstock Champion Vittorio lannuzzo on  an 
Alstare Suzuki GSX-R1000 that was of  a much lower 
spec than the  Spaniards bike. 
Laguna Seca is one of the  most breathtaking circuits 
on  the  calendar, with the  infamous Corkscrew at  its 
heart providing a  riding experience like  no  other. It 
doesn’t help that wild-card riders always want to  put 
one  over the  Superbike regulars and  can  use  their 
superior local knowledge to  good advantage. Led  by 
Yoshimura USA's Mat Mladin, the  locals were good 
in  qualifying but  couldn't produce the  goods in either 
race; Mladin didn't even take part in Race 2, citing 
‘fatigue’. Xaus led  the  first race, and looked on  course 
170 World Superbikes: The  First 20  Years 
for win  number three, but then crashed out  leaving Chili 
to  inherit the  victory. Hodgson consolidated his series 
lead with second, ahead of Toseland and Mladin. Race 
2 saw Ruben more than make up for  his earlier fall, 
taking his third win  in four races by an  easy 11  seconds. 
Second again was Hodgson, with Walker third and 
Laconi fourth, ahead of a  bruised and  battered Lavilla. 
Both races had  been all-action affairs, which was  just 
as  well as  there were two major announcements that 
sent shock waves through the  paddock. First, SBK CEO 
Paolo Flammini announced that Pirelli would be the 
one-make tyre supplier in 2004. Second, and no  less 
significant, was the  MSMA statement that none of the 
major factories, or  Aprilia, would be  running their new 
superbikes in the  series. 
The  two-week gap  between Laguna Seca and  Brands 
Hatch gave everybody time to  digest this  news but, if 
there was doom and  gloom around, it certainly didn’t 
affect the  racing at one of the  sport’s most popular 
venues. The  weather had  been poor on  both practice 
days but  stayed dry for  race day —  good for the  fans, 
but  not  for the  SBK  regulars who'd had  hardly any  dry 
track time. Shane Byrne joined a  long list of locals who 
have ‘done good’ when they've competed at their 
home round, winning both races at the  undulating Kent 
circuit. He  used his  long-time track knowledge to  blitz 
the  opposition, though Race 2 was a  much tougher 
call. Britons filled all the  remaining rostrum places, 
too  (Hodgson and  Walker in the  first race, Reynolds 
and  Toseland in the  second), bettering the  result at 
Oschersleben earlier in the  year. Xaus was now 140 
points behind Hodgson, with only a  possible 150  points 
remaining, having DNFd in Race 1 and  then taken 
fourth. But  at  least he was better off than Petronas. 
Three DNFs and a finish outside the  points were hardly 
what they’d have hoped for,  or  might have expected, at 
a  ‘home’ event. 

Hodgson had  become a father just before Assen and 
he celebrated that, and winning the  title, with a second 
place in Race 1. On  his slow-down lap the  crowd, 
full  of the  usual legion of British fans, was treated 
to  Hodgson’s T-shirt bearing the  slogan ‘Who's your 
Daddy?’ It was almost like  the  glory days of another 
Lancastrian, Carl Fogarty, though perhaps lacking the 
same intensity. The first race had been a  nervy, close- 
quarter, four-way affair, with Xaus and  Hodgson both 
littering the  6.027-km circuit with mistakes; they finished 
in that order, with Chill third and  Toseland losing out 
on  the  run  to the  flag. Chili had  taken Superpole with a 
time only a second slower than the  best of the  MotoGP 
boys earlier in the  year —  and on  a  Ducati two levels 
below Hodgson’s. In Race 2 the  new champion, freed of 
pressure, got  his own back on  his team-mate, winning 
his  12th race of the year by almost half  a second. Lavilla 
was a distant third, to  make up for  his  DNF in Race 
1, and  even Petronas had a positive day, with Corser 
coming sixth and  ninth. 
The  title  might have been decided before Imola, with 
Xaus virtually assured the  runner-up spot, but  it didn’t 
stop the  Fila  team-mates slugging it out, lap after lap, 
for top spot at  Ducati’s home circuit. In the  first  part 
of the  season Xaus had  struggled with the  new 
999 FO3, but  Imola was a  perfect example of how far 
he’d progressed and, although Hodgson had  lost  none 
of his determination and  tried everything he knew (and 
more!), the  Spaniard was too  strong. Third went to 
Laconi, with Lavilla fourth and  Chili a tremendous fifth 
after starting from pit lane. Hodgson outbraked himself 
in Race 2 and  lost  places as  he thundered through the 
gravel. To  his credit, he fought back and  even managed 
to  pass Walker in the  final stages. Xaus was again the 
comfortable winner, taking the flag some 12  seconds 
ahead of Laconi, with Lavilla third. Toseland failed to 
score, but  Corser and  Petronas had  more cause for 
optimism with a  pair of sevenths. The  biggest story of 
the weekend, though, was Michelin lining up their top  - 
duo of Hodgson and  Xaus on  what seemed to  be  rear 
cut  slicks. There had  been no  change in track conditions, 
so  what were the  French company playing at?  According 
to their spokesman, it was the  first  use  of the  type of 
(production?) tyre they'd intended to  run  in Supersport 
in 2004 —  had  they not  been denied the  chance by the 
FGSport/Pirelli tie-up. It was obvious that Pirelli didn’t 
believe this, preferring to think of the  rubber on  show 
as  merely hand-cut clicks made to  look like  Michelin’s 
DOT offerings. Whatever the  point, it was a  more than 
effective message to those concerned. 
Magny-Cours in mid-October is not  renowned 
for  its warm, balmy conditions and  although rain 
wasn’t on  the  menu, bitterly cold conditions were. 
The  track temperature never rose above 21°C, even 
in the  afternoon, and  the  freezing cold caused many 
fallers, with just  15 finishers in Race 1 and 17  in Race 
2.  Hodgson led  the  charge in the  first race, despite his 
boot almost coming loose, taking his  13th win  of the 
season. Once again it was team-mate Xaus who pushed 
him  all the  way, even though he’d only qualified eighth. 
Ruben rode with determined but  controlled aggression 
to finish a very close second, leaving many wondering 
why he'd not  done that from the  start, and  then took a 
very comfortable win  in the  second race, a total of seven 
victories from his  last twelve outings. Toseland posted 
fifth and  second places to  secure third spot overall in the 
championship on  271, just four points clear of Laconi. 
James then performed a  burn-out with friend and 
team-mate Walker, happy in the  knowledge that 2004 
would see  him  in an  all-changed factory Ducati team 
alongside his French rival. Walker's prospects were not 
so  clear, though he'd ended the  season strongly with 
two thirds, finishing sixth overall. Lavilla’s two fourths 
also saw him  fourth in the  championship, ahead of 
Chili, who had suffered a  pair of DNFs. The new boys, 
Petronas, fizzled out  with just an  eighth place from 
Corser in the  penultimate race. As  starts go,  it had  been 
an  inauspicious one, but  there was always 2004 to  look 
forward to.

own to  the  wire’ is  an  oft-used expression in 
motorsport, but never can it have been more

race of the  year Briton James Toseland had to  overcome 
odds that would have got  the  better of most riders, 
but  to  go  to  the  cauldron of Magny-Cours, behind in 
points to  team-mate Regis Laconi, and come out  the 
winner in  front of the  Frenchman's home crowd was 
one of the  great moments in  World Superbike history 
And Toseland also went into  the  record books as  the 
youngest-ever title-holder, eclipsing Aussie Troy Corser’s 
achievement eight years earlier 
Although James was only 23  he’d already been 
racing for  nine years on  tarmac, starting with the  UK 
Junior Road Racing Series in  1995 and  winning the 
Honda CB500 Cup in  the  UK  at just 16.  His  rise  to  World 
Superbike glory hadn't been either steady or  meteoric; 
instead, he  came up  through the  school of hard knocks, 
suffering breaks to  both ankles, a fractured femur 
and spells with uncompetitive machinery, but  always 
displaying a  gritty approach to  racing. He  fought all  his 
demons and, once he  started his  World Superbike career 
with Team GSE, there would be  no  doubt as  to  his 
desire and determination to  be  a  winner 
The 2004 season did  not start promisingly, however 
Ducati were still  the  only factory team involved, despite 
the  dropping of the  controversial ‘restricters’ rule from 
the  previous year. The factory boycott (real or  perceived 
by the  Japanese manufacturers did  not  bode well for 
the  11-race series, and the  single-make tyre regulations 
didn’t help either. World Superbike was being regarded 
by some as  at  its  lowest ebb for  years, while for 
others, such as  series bosses the  Flammini Group, the 
lack of factory involvement meant the  championship 
was returning to  Its  roots and the  one-make tyre | 
would help, not hinder, that return. Paolo Flammi 
the  Group's CEO, had noted MotoGP’s ever-spiralling 
World Superbikes: The First 20  Years 175 



costs and knew there was no  way the  World Superbike 
Championship could go  the  same way. What he and 
the  Flammini Group put  in  place was a  gamble, no 
doubt, but  by the  end  of the  year it wasn’t looking such 
a  bad idea —  and  the  proof was consistently close and 
exciting racing. Furthermore, the  Big Four were gearing 
themselves up  to  return, albeit with importer, dealer or 
privateer teams. 
With 2004 champ Hodgson and runner-up Ruben 
Xaus off  to  MotoGP, the  factory Fila  Ducati team called 
up  the  riders who'd placed third and  fourth in  the 
2003 standings —  Toseland and Laconi. Both had  been 
with satellite Ducati teams, so  it was almost a  smooth 
transition. What was not  so  smooth, though, was the 
move to  the  new one-make Pirelli tyres and  all  the 
problems that entailed. Fila  Ducati found themselves, 
uncharacteristically, in the  same boat as  everybody else, 
something they'd probably not  experienced since the 
championship’s early years. Their 999 FO4s were not 
appreciably different from the  2003 bikes —  they didn’t 
really have to  be, after all —  but  strangely it was the 
chassis that proved tricky at  times. Indeed, Toseland 
would spend a large part of the  season not  being 
comfortable with the  bike and it took a  private Mugello 
test  in the  summer before he felt  at  home with the 
machine. Once he did, he took two wins and  was on  the 
podium six times in the  last  six  races. He  might only have 
won three races compared to  his  team-mate’s seven, but 
he  DNFd three times to  Laconi’s five  and  that difference 
—  and his  unbelievable performance in the  last  round 
—  was enough to take the  title. 
Their biggest challenge came from the  ‘Samurai 
of Slide’, Noriyuki Haga, on  the  Ducati 999 RSO4, the

The  other challenge to Toseland and Laconi came 
from a  most unlikely source: rookie team Ten  Kate 
Honda. The Dutch outfit had  won the World Supersport 
title  the  year before and decided to  play with the  big 
boys in 2004, using the  new 1000cc Fireblade piloted 
by their Supersport Champion, Aussie Chris Vermeulen. 
At the  beginning of the  year, and  in the  early races, 
the  bike was more of a  road bike with some race 
parts instead of a fully fledged member of the  World 
Superbike fast  club, but  the  CBR1OOORR just got better 
and better as  the  season progressed. Ten  Kate were 
quick to  point out  that theirs was not  a  ‘factory HRC’ 
bike by any  means, rather it was all their own work 
—  with a little help from their friends in Japan. 
Foggy Petronas returned for their second season 
with a  new engine partner: Ricardo Engineering took 
over from Suter Racing Technologies. Troy Corser was 
joined by Chris Walker but, although the  team took a 
couple of podium finishes and  two Superpoles, it was 
another tough year for the  British-based outfit. The 
evergreen Chili showed up  again, on  one  of the  new 
999RS Ducatis, and  took to  it like  a duck to  a frozen 
lake. Frankie just didn’t get on  with the  new bike 
and  it wasn’t long before the  paddock was treated 
to  one  he and  the  team had  made earlier —  a 998.5 
as  he affectionately called it.  It was part 999RS and 
part 998FO2 and  gave the  Italian the  feel  he wanted 
—and it was legal. Not  that the  (Italian) organisers of 
the  series would have thrown out  one  of the  crowd's 
favourites, even if the  bike was a bit of a sore point

for  Ducati. Alstare Suzuki were noticeable absentees, 
having decided to  sit the  year out, so  the  Hamamatsu 
flag was carried mainly by Chinese company Zongshen. 
With Superbike veteran Piergiorgio Bontempi and former 
World Endurance Champion Warwick Nowland on 
board, the  riders had  pedigree, but  with zero factory 
involvement their highest finish was ninth. 
The  first race took place in  Valencia, in late  February, 
and  it was clearly too  early in the  year for  most of the 
players, with only the  factory Ducati team really ready. It 
was also the  first time with the  new Pirelli control tyres 
and  the  initial effect was slower lap times than previous 
seasons. Conditions on  race-day morning were tricky, to 
say  the  least, with rain  giving way to  a  drying track and 
causing a variety of tyre choices. There were numerous 
fallers, including Laconi, who only got as  far as  Turn 2 
on  the  opening lap. Team-mate Toseland took the win, 
despite pressure from Chili and Steve Martin throughout 
the  23-lapper. The unlucky Aussie should have had  third, 
but  his  privateer Ducati blew up just two laps from the 
end, letting Walker into  third place —  and  the  first-ever 
podium for  Foggy Petronas. Haga took a comfortable 
win  in Race 2, with Toseland second and Martin getting 
his just rewards with a third place. The hapless Laconi 
once again failed to score, though this  time it was his 
chain coming off  rather than any  mistake of his own. 
At  Round 2, in Phillip Island, Laconi made up for  his 
weekend to forget in Spain by completely dominating 
the  first race, running out  the  winner by a whopping 
seven seconds. Behind, though, was a thrilling four-rider 
battle between Vermeulen, Toseland, Martin and McCoy 
for the  remaining podium places. In a frantic dash to the 
line  Vermeulen took runner-up spot, with Toseland third, 
but the  gap  between Chris and  fifth-placed McCoy 
was  just seven-tenths of a second at the  flag. Former 
MotoGP race winner McCoy then gave his  home fans a 
treat by taking victory in Race 2, despite luridly sliding 
his 999 Ducati the whole way round the 4.445-km 
circuit. Fellow-countryman Vermeulen was second, Chili 
third, with Borciani’s privateer Ducati fourth, ahead of 
yet another Aussie, Corser, in fifth. Martin had  been 
fighting McCoy for the  lead in the  race, but  another 
blow-up saw his challenge evaporate three laps from 
the  end. Although lap times were down compared to 
previous years, the  fans enjoyed a spectacle of rear-end 
slides, smoking tyres and  closer racing, with the  four 
races to  date producing four different winners. 
Misano was the  scene for  Round 3, in April rather 
than its usual summertime slot  —  and  it seemed the 
move was not  a good one, for the  weekend was 
blighted by rain. At  least the  home fans left the  Adriatic 
circuit happy because Chili's third in Race 1 and 
emotional victory in the  second race were enough to 
move the  Italian into  the  title  lead. The  first race was 
shortened by a  lap after Bontempi’s Suzuki failed to fire 
up  on  the  start line  and  then stopped after 17  laps due 
to the  adverse conditions. Corser had  put the  Petronas 
in front for the  best part of the  first 14  laps, but  Laconi 
overtook him  just before the  heavens opened again. 
Troy had  been tantalisingly close to  giving the  Malaysian 

company its  first-ever win, but  runner-up spot was 
the  best result of their short World Superbike history 
Chili was ahead of Haga and Vermeulen, with Walker's 
sixth making it two Petronas bikes in  the  top  six.  Series 
leader Toseland had only qualified 20th, but  a  gritty 
tenth kept his  points tally ticking over. Race 2 was wet 
and rain-master Chili took the  win after slipping and 
sliding around in  the  early stages behind Laconi. The 
Frenchman held second comfortably, with Martin taking 
a thoroughly well-deserved third. Toseland charged to 
sixth place and  20  points behind Chili going into Round 
4, knowing it was going to  be yet another ‘home’ race 
for the  Italian. 
There had  now been five  different winners in six 
races, but  Monza saw something of a  return to  normal 
business. The  factory Ducati team of Laconi and 
Toseland took a  1-2  in both races and, to  keep the 
podium symmetrical, McCoy took two thirds. If Ducati 
had  been unhappy about Chili's adoption of old  chassis 
and new engine in  his  998.5 they must have had  a wry 
smile as  the  Italian suffered two DNFs. In  Race 1 his 
bike failed at the  first  chicane and  he  had  to  ‘borrow’ 
a  scooter to  get  back to  pit lane and  jump onto his 
unfavoured 999. 
He  started dead last, but  got  up  to  14th after five 
laps before his  engine went bang. Worse was to  come in 
Race 2, when he crashed at  the  Parabolica after pushing 
the  front too  hard. The  ever-popular Italian's pair of 
no-scores dropped him  from first to third behind new 
championship leader Laconi and team-mate Toseland 
Oschersleben is  not  a  fast circuit and overtaking 
is  difficult, but  Haga showed that he was completely 
at  home in  the  twisty bits  by taking the  chequered 
flag in  Race 1, some five  seconds in  front of Toseland. 
Chill made up  for some of his  Monza disappointment 
by taking third place, and Corser and Petronas had  a 
good race, finishing fourth. The  German track suited 
the  sweet-handling Petronas, where power is  not  at 
a  premium, but  Troy couldn't repeat the  feat in  Race 
2, retiring like  so  many others. There were only 14 
finishers, Laconi won the  race by a  massive 21  seconds 
from Toseland and fellow-Briton Haslam took third. 
Haga had led  the  race and looked set  for  a superb 
double, but  his  unreliable bike let  him  down again, 
six  laps from the  end. Toseland’s pair of seconds took 
him  back to  the  top  of the  standings, but  the  margin 
between him  and Laconi was just  two points. 
Toseland was hoping for  a home success at 
Silverstone, but  although the  crowd could enjoy the 
sunshine they didn’t get the  result they wanted. James 
failed to  finish in  the  first  race and  only managed fifth 
in the  second. Fortunately for  him, Laconi also had 
a  first-race crash, so  the  points damage was limited. 
Haga took his third win  of the  year, narrowly beating 
Vermeulen after 20  action-packed laps, with Chili third. 
Race 2 saw history made, with Vermeulen giving a 
1000cc four-cylinder bike its first-ever World Superbike 
win. It was also the  championship’s 400th race and

he  2005 season was a  landmark year, with a 
series of multiple firsts. Troy Corser became the 
first rider in  the  history of the  series to  win the  World 
Championship for  two different manufacturers; it was 
the  first-ever title for  Suzuki and for  a  1000cc four- 
cylinder bike; and it was a first for  Team Alstare. Troy's 
previous title had been nine years earlier, in  1996, when 
he was in  the semi-privateer Promotor Ducati team, 
and he’d also been leading in  1998 until a  bad crash in 
the  last round, at  Sugo, when he  broke three ribs and 
ruptured his  spleen. He  spent two seasons with Aprilia 
and was with Foggy Petronas for  2003-4, but  when the 
chance came to  ride  for  Francis Batta’s Alstare outfit, on 
the  new Suzuki GSX-R1000, he jumped at  it 
Alstare carried out  an  extensive programme of 
winter tests and when the  season began Corser and 
the  team came out  of the  starting blocks firing on  all 
four cylinders. If anybody thought the  Aussie’s desire to 
win had been blunted by his  semi-wilderness years, his 
victory in  the  first race of the  year, starting a  run  of six 
wins in  the  first  seven races, dispelled any  misgivings 
The  groundwork for  the  title  was done before the  rest 
had a  chance to  catch their breath and it was eight 
rounds and 16 races before Troy failed to  get  on  the 
podium. He  didn’t manage a  win after Brands Hatch, 
but he kept his  points tally ticking over, and even though 
Vermeulen outscored him in  the latter stages he  had 
done more than enough to  become champion 
The 2005 series was the  second year of  the  Pirelli 
one-make tyre rule and it  received a  couple of  fillips 
before the  very early start; first, all  the  Japanese 
manufacturers returned in  some form or  another 
(though it’s  difficult to   know exactly how ‘factory 
they were) and second, the  series got  a  title sponsor 
—-  Corona, which brought glamour in  the  shape of  the 
Corona girls and very welcome supplies of  their beer! 
The number of  teams taking part increased substantially 
from the year before, with 30  riders regularly lined up

The  factory Ducati team changed sponsors (Xerox 
instead of Fila)  but  kept the  same riders —  2004 champ 
James Toseland and  Frenchman Regis Laconi —  though it 
would prove to  be a  hard year for them and  the  Bologna 
marque. Their new 999FO5 bikes had  been completely 
revamped, with huge work done to the  electronics 
and injection systems. Improvements in the  engine 
department liberated another five  horsepower and 
that, together with the  rest  of the  factory mods, meant 
there was now quite a  difference between them and 
the  customer bikes. A relative lack  of winter tests meant 
they had  to  play catch-up but, once they got there, they 
proved equal to  the  best of the  Japanese bikes. 
The  Ten  Kate CBR1000RR Hondas received a  boost 
in the  form of sponsorship from tobacco company 
Winston, which meant a change from yellow to  blue 
and  white. Chris Vermeulen was  joined by fellow- 
countryman and 2004 World Supersport Champion, Karl 
Muggeridge and, despite getting their material late, the 
Dutch outfit were fast  from the  start. 
Italian-based PSG-1 ran  the  top  Kawasaki team in 
2005, with Chris Walker on  board, partnered by Mauro 
Sanchini. The  bike was clearly fast, thanks to  its  French 
engine tuners Akira, but  the  chassis caused quite a 
few  problems and  gave the  team a lot of work to  do 
throughout the  season. 
After taking a year out, Alstare Suzuki came back 
with a  bang. Having secured the  services of long-

enjoyed support from Japan, but  insisted that GSX- 
R1000 bikes were tuned and  fettled in Belgium. The 
new bikes were well balanced, had  a  strong torque 
range and  benefited from factory Showa suspension, 
complete with a dedicated technician. There was further 
Japanese content with the  welcome arrival of Yukio 
Kagayama, a  long-time favourite in the  British Superbike 
Championship and  self-confessed ‘crazy rider’. He  wasn't 
in the  team just to  make up  the  numbers, though 
—he won the  second race and  left  the  first  round as 
championship leader. 
Petronas FP-1 had  a  new team-manager, Jack 
Valentine, and new top-name riders in  Steve Martin and 
Garry McCoy, but  their 900cc triple was always destined 
to  struggle against the  massed hordes of  1000cc fours. 
The original concept of a triple, with a  reversed cylinder 
head, was clearly up  against it and no  amount of rider 
skill  or  commitment could make up  for the  machine's 
failings. 
lf Corser and Suzuki had been a  marriage made in 
heaven (or  at  least Hamamatsu), then Noriyuki Haga 
and Yamaha were an  equivalent pairing. The R1  had 
been a  potent tool in  the  Superstock class and  the  newly 
formed Yamaha Motor Italia squad had  the  look of a 
‘factory team’, based as  they were in  the  same building 
as  Yamaha's MotoGP squad. Former World Supersport 
Champion Andrew Pitt  joined Haga on a bike that 
started the  season more Superstock than Superbike and 
it was the  seventh round before rider and bike worked

in perfect harmony and recorded their first win. 
The increased grid saw the  return of Ben Bostrom, 
who replaced Haga in the  Renegade team (now on 
CBR1000RR Hondas) from the  year before. It was a 
frustratingly mixed season of crashes and  few highlights 
for the  American, due  to the  unreliability of the  bikes 
and behind-the-scenes squabbles. Also Honda-mounted 
was the  oldest racer in the  field, Pierfrancesco Chili, and 
the  youngest, Max Neukirchner, both riding for Team 
Klaffi Honda. Like  Team Renegade (and many others) 
they'd spend most of the  year trying to  improve their 
bikes. Yamaha Motor France entered the  fray with 
former GP  winner Norick Abe and  Sébastien Gimbert, 
and two other ex-GP riders —  Fonsi Nieto (partnered 
by rising Italian Lorenzo Lanzi) in Team Ducati SC 
Caracchi and fellow-Spaniard José Luis  Cardoso (Yamaha 
DFXtreme) —  also  joined the  Superbike club. 
So  a  new era  for World Superbikes and a  new track 
for the  first race of the  year: Losail, Qatar. The  facility 
was brand new and had  everything a  modern race track 
could offer; the  only thing missing was the  fans. Not 
that Corser and team-mate Kagayama noticed, for  each 
took a win and a  podium to  give Alstare Suzuki a  dream 
start and leave the  rest of the  pack worried. It was the 
first time in  the  history of the  series that Suzuki had 
scored a  double and, ominously, looked like  it wouldn't 
be the  last. Troy’s win in  Race 1 came after an  unusual 
occurrence in  the  desert: rain! The race started dry, 
but  when rain  began to  fall  after ten  laps, and Laconi 
crashed as  the  conditions worsened, it was red-flagged. 

Kagayama won the  second part ‘on  the  road’, but 
Corser had  stuck close by in  second and  took the  overall 
win, with Laconi third. New boy Pitt  took fourth, with 
team-mate Haga fifth and  2004 champion Toseland 
sixth. In the  second race, a  too-hard rear  tyre cost 
Corser the  double and  he  had  to settle for third, but  at 
least team-mate Kagayama won, with Laconi second. 
Eight riders began the  battle for fourth, with Vermeulen 
taking the  honours ahead of Chili and  Toseland —  not  an 
auspicious start for the  former GP  stars, with Abe's pair 
of top tens the  best of the  bunch. It was, however, a  lot 
better than Petronas, who managed just a  single point 
between them. 
If ever a  rider was made for  Phillip Island, that rider 
was Troy Corser —  especially when he  had  the  right 
tool for the job. He  and  the  GSX-R1000 had  topped 
the  tests there and  should have led  the  charge in 
qualifying, but  he found himself way down the  pecking 
order after Superpole —  even behind the  Petronas. Chili 
was a  non-starter, thanks to  a  broken collarbone, and 
the  new 1000cc four-cylinder bikes were surprisingly 
outgunned (in top  speed anyway) by Laconi’s Ducati, 
which burst through the  speed trap at a  staggering 
318km/h (197.6mph). Only 16  riders finished Race 1, 
due  to crashes and  other DNFs, with Corser taking 
the win, eight seconds ahead of team-mate (and 
Superpole winner), Kagayama. Vermeulen used his  local 
knowledge to take third, but  only after a  battle with 
rookie Neukirchner, which saw both paint and rubber 
traded. The  good news for the  start of Race 2 was that 
the  wind had  died down; the  bad  news was rain  after 
12  laps, which caused the  red  flag to come out. And 
so,  for the  second time in two rounds, another two- 
parter. Conditions were tricky to  say  the  least, and  there 
were numerous fallers, notably at the  Hayshed, where 
Walker, Pitt  and Haga all succumbed. Laconi managed a 
spectacular ‘save’ there, only to fall  further up  the  hill  at 
Lukey Heights. He  restarted and  took seventh place in a 
race that saw only 14 finishers. Corser kept his  head to  . 
take his second win  of the  day, with Kagayama second 
and Neukirchner a  superb third. 
The  Corser roadshow continued its  momentum at 
Valencia, with yet another double for the  Alstare rider, 
but  the  big surprise of the  weekend was that none of 
the  Ducatis really featured on  a track that’s normally 
their kind of territory. The  best they could manage was 
Toseland’s ninth in the  first  race and  no  Ducati (factory 
Or  private) even got  a  point in the  second —  a  big change 
from the  year before when they practically filled the 
top  ten. Honda was Suzuki's main challenger, with 
Vermeulen taking a  pair of runner-up spots. Kagayama 
was third in  Race 1 and  Walker third on  the  Kawasaki 
in  Race 2, leaving only Yamaha without a  podium 
place so  far.  Laconi didn’t even get to  the  start line: a 
heavy fall  in  qualifying left  him  with concussion and  the 
doctors wisely ruled him  out. Neukirchner was back in 
the  news again, this  time for different reasons, when 
he suffered the  biggest highside of the  year in  the  first 
race, his sliding Honda taking out  Lanzi before pushing 
Muggeridge off  track. The  Italian broke his  collarbone,

Monza’s fast  track makes for fast  racing, and  should 
really have favoured the  1000cc fours, bur  Bologna’s 
finest showed a  huge improvement after their sluggish 
start and were competitive again. It wasn’t quite 
enough to  stop Corser racking up win number six  out 
of seven starts, but  they did  take two podiums. As 
usual, the  Italian circuit served a feast of high-speed 
action, with the  opening race ending with just 1.75s 
covering the  top  four. Kagayama played wingman to 
Corser, with Toseland third and Laconi fourth. The Ten 
Kate Hondas should have been challengers but, for 
some unaccountable reason, the  team decided not  to 
use  the  special ‘Monza’ motors in  Race 1. The plan 
failed for Vermeulen when his  CBR1000RR ground to  an 
undignified halt  after only a  lap.  In  Race 2, the  ‘Monza’ 
motor went in and  Vermeulen stole the  win, a  mere 
half-second ahead of Laconi. Corser took third, after 
complaining about brake problems, ahead of Toseland 
and  Pitt.  There had  been eight riders contesting the 
lead at one  stage of the  race, conclusive proof that you 
don't need the  fastest bike to  have a  good result at a 
fast  track. 
The  season took an  unpredictable turn at  Silverstone 
when Laconi and  Toseland gave Ducati a win  apiece. 
Normally the  Northants track is suited to the  high-speed 
fours, despite the  mickey-mouse chicane just before the 
start-finish straight, but the  use  of the  so-called shorter 
‘International’ circuit negated much of the  1000cc bikes’ 
advantage. There was universal disapproval, from riders 
and  teams alike, especially as  the  information about 
which circuit was to  be  used was only discovered a 
week or  so  before the  event. Nevertheless, the  racing 
was exciting, the  result unexpected and  the  crowd 
enjoyed Toseland taking a win  on  home soil. James was 
also in contention in the  first race, but  that was won by 
team-mate Laconi, with Corser second. However, a win 
and a third for  Ducati was a  huge turnaround, and  a 
great relief to  Ducatisti everywhere. Corser led  most of 
the  second race until overtaken by Toseland, then settled 
for  runner-up spot after Laconi crashed out  and Haga 
wasn’t close enough to  cause any  problems, knowing 
he’d increased his championship lead over his  nearest 
rival —  team-mate Kagayama. 
Misano returned to  its traditional summer slot, 
much to  everybody’s relief, except perhaps Pirelli: track 
temperatures were in the  fifties on  race day. Ducati’s 
recent testing programme (riders and tyres) reaped 
dividends, with Laconi winning both races. Vermeulen 
took a  pair  of seconds, Corser a  pair of thirds and  the 
symmetry even extended to Toseland’ s pair  of fourths. 
Although the  top  four may have been the  same in  both 
24-lap races, they were very different kettles of fish. 
Laconi ran  away with Race 1, four seconds in  front of 
Vermeulen, with Corser a further four seconds adrift; 
Race 2 was a  much closer affair. And Kagayama lost  his 
second place in  the  championship. He’d been fined for a 
fist  fight with Spaniard Cardoso in  qualifying and maybe 
the  red  mist hadn't cleared in  time for  race day. A crash

v 
after 15  laps of the first race put him  out  and  injured 
his hand. He then had  to  use  his number two bike and 
could only manage 12th place in the  second. His  behind- 
the-scenes work testing for the  Suzuka 8 Hour was cited 
as  a factor in his  loss  of form and, true or  not, it would 
be the  last  race of the  year before he saw the  podium 
again. 
It had  been nine years since the  Superbike circus 
had  been to  Brno, a  long-time favourite with fans, and 
this  year’s race saw ‘Nitro-Nori’ Haga break his and 
Yamaha's winning duck. His  previous best result so  far 
had  been a third at Silverstone, but  his  performance 
in Race 2 was nothing short of sensational and  even 
outclassed series leader Corser. Troy had  been without 
a win  since Monza and  many observers were beginning . 
to  think that, once again, the  wheels were beginning 
to  come off the  Aussie’s wagon. Not  this  time. He 
dominated practice, and Superpole, and stormed his 
way to victory In Race 1, finishing over six seconds ahead 
of Toseland, with Laconi third and  Walker fourth. He 
was on  course for another double, but  he’d reckoned 
without Haga. The  Japanese rider hadn't even qualified 
for  Superpole and his  18th position on  the  grid meant 
he had  to  do  something really special. Nobody had  ever 
won a  Superbike race from outside the  top  16  before, 
but  Haga didn’t care about statistics. Lap after lap he 
charged though the  field, at  record pace, forcing his way 
through gaps that didn’t exist until nobody was in front. 
Those fortunate enough to witness it will  never forget 
it—  and  that probably includes runner-up Corser, third- 
placed Vermeulen and the  rest  of the  riders who saw a 
flash of blue and  white go  past. 
As  usual the  biggest race on  the  World Superbike 
calendar was Brands Hatch and, as  ever, the  on-track 
action didn’t disappoint the  massed crowds. Haga, 
fresh from his victory in Brno, was the  only rider to  give

Corser a  hard time in the  opening race. The  duo  stuck 
to each other like  glue throughout the  25-lapper, with 
the  lead changing hands no  less  than seven times, but 
in the  end  Troy just sneaked it, by less  than two-tenths 
of a second. Laconi took third, with Vermeulen fourth 
and  crowd favourite Walker fifth. Toseland DNFd with 
an  ‘electrical problem’, much to the  dismay of his  legions 
of fans looking for  a home win  for the  number-one 
plate-holder. If Race 1 was a  Corser/Haga thriller, Race 
2 was even more of the  same —  if that were possible! 
With nearest title  rival  Vermeulen finishing only fourth in 
the  first  Troy didn’t need to win, but  that didn’t prevent 
him  pulling out  all the  stops and  giving Nori a  helluva 
fight. For  virtually every lap there was hardly daylight 
between them. They tangled on  the  back part of the 
4.197-km circuit —  far from the  eyes of the  crowd, but 
visible on  the  big-screen monitors —  with Corser running 
off-track. He  got  back on  course but  that excursion into 
the  dirt  gave Haga just the  gap he  needed to  take the 
chequered flag. Vermeulen was third, a  long way down, 
with Walker netting his second fourth place of the 
day. Two fantastic races with the  top four in each race 
different manufacturers —  what more could the  series 
ask  for? 
If Vermeulen needed to  reassert himself, Assen was 
a  good place to  do  it.  His  Ten  Kate team’s headquarters 
were just down the  road and  hordes of home fans were 
ready and willing to  provide vocal support. Like Brands, 
Assen is  another great Superbike venue and  although 
the  circuit had  been remodelled there was still  enough 
of the  ‘old’ Assen to  please riders and  fans. The  racing 
was top  notch, too, with the  track still  favouring the 
best and  fastest riders. Vermeulen started his campaign 
well, by taking Superpole, and  then fastest lap in  Race 1, 
a  record that will  last  forever as  it would be the  last  year 
of the  North Loop. Four riders disputed the  lead until

Chris decided it was going to  be  his  race, leaving behind 
a frenetic battle between Haga, Corser and  Toseland, 
with James taking second and  Nori third. Corser was 
fourth —  the first  time he’d not  been on  the  podium all 
year. Race 2 was a straight three-way fight: Vermeulen, 
Haga, Toseland. All three led  several times, but the 
young Aussie just held off  Haga out  of the  final chicane 
to take the flag by 0.85s. Toseland was  third, Corser 
off the  podium again in fourth. A crisis? Maybe. But  at 
least he was  better off than Laconi. The  Frenchman had 
crashed in qualifying, injuring the tendons in his elbow, 
removing skin  from his arm  as  he made contact with 
first  the tarmac and  then his bike. It was  the  second 
time this year he’d been forced to  miss races after a 
practice crash. 
Throughout the  season young Italian Lorenzo Lanzi 
had been doing well on  the  SC  Caracchi Ducati, and 
when the  factory Xerox Ducati team looked for a 
replacement for Laconi at Lausitz the  choice was simple 
but obvious. Lanzi took his chance right from the  start 
of practice and  surprised even the  Ducati top  brass by 
winning Superpole. Could he go on  to take victory as 
well? Championship leader Corser’s non-podium finishes 
in Assen had  given his nearest challenger, Vermeulen, 
a glimmer of hope and  the  deficit was now down to 
86  points —  still  a good lead, but  not  an  impossible 
target. Lanzi got overexcited at the  start of Race 1 and 
completely lost  his Superpole advantage by going into 
the first  turn too  hot. He  had  to take to the  slip road 
and, by the  time he  recovered, he was in the  middle of 
the  pack. Vermeulen kept up  his winning streak, making 
it three in a  row, with Haga second and  Corser third, in 
a  race halted by rain  on  lap 20  out  of 24. Maybe seeing 
his young countryman on  the  up was  what prompted 
Corser to  push so  hard in Race 2. Too  hard as  it turned 
out, as  he lost the front going into  Turn 1 and  crashed. 
Troy picked up the  bike and  got going again, dead last, 
but  rode the wheels off his Suzuki to take 13th place. 
At the  sharp end  Lanzi showed that his qualifying and 
Superpole form had  been no  fluke, controlling the  race 
and  running out  the winner 0.84s ahead of Vermeulen, 
with Haga third. Kagayama’s fifth and  fourth confirmed 
he'd now completely recovered from his trips to and 
from Japan on  Suzuka 8 Hour duties. 
Laconi was deemed fit for  Imola, so  Lausitz hero 
Lanzi moved back to the  SC  Caracchi squad, though this 
time he had  factory engines to  play with. A large part 
of the  crowd had  come to see  the  young Italian and 
even the wet  conditions didn’t put them off,  but they 
were destined to  leave the  old  circuit feeling robbed. 
A rainstorm of biblical proportions flooded the track 
after Race 1, causing deep puddles round the 4.933-km 
circuit. The drains did  their best, but  lakes of standing 
water and  small rivers running across the  track caused 
the  top  riders to stop the  second race’s proceedings 
before they started. The  start was delayed, then delayed 
further, and  finally Corser, Vermeulen and  Laconi went 
out  in pace cars  to take a closer look. They confirmed 
what everybody feared, but  it was Race Control who 
made the  decision to cancel Race 2.  The  decision 
also meant that Corser was World Champion, for the 
second time, depriving Vermeulen of the  chance to 
take the  fight to the  last  round in Magny-Cours. All  this 
overshadowed events in Race 1, where Vermeulen had 
taken victory in difficult conditions. The  race started 
wet, then the  track began to dry out  as  he and  Corser 
sought to  master both each other and  the  conditions. 
At  the end  there was only 0.297s between them, with 
Haga a  distant third, Toseland fourth, Martin fifth and 
Walker sixth. Six different manufacturers in the  top six 
was a vindication of FGSport’s decision to  go with the 
one-make tyre rule; it was  just a shame that the  rain 
came down and  decided everything. 
There was still  plenty to fight for at  Magny-Cours 
—  apart from first and  second places in the  standings 
—  and  even new champ Corser and  Vermeulen wanted 
to end  the  season on a high. Troy was  taken out  of the 
equation early on  with a  disastrous Superpole, through 
no  fault of his own. Unknown to  him, at least until 
the  first turn or  so,  a team member had  over-inflated 
his  rear  tyre by a substantial margin and he spent the 
whole lap slipping and  sliding around the  track with 
clouds of smoke coming from his  rear  tyre. Entertaining 
to watch, but  an  unsatisfactory 16th-quickest lap time 
and  a fourth-row start as  a  result, so  it’s to  his credit 
he still  found the  hunger to fight his way up to fifth in 
the first race and  an  even better fourth in the  second. 
Vermeulen continued his run  of good form by leading 
from the  start of Race 1 and  was  never headed on  his 
way to  a comfortable eight-second victory. Kagayama 
took second with Toseland third and  Muggeridge 
fourth, not  far ahead of the  charging Corser. The  start 
of Race 2 witnessed one  of the  most dramatic first-lap 
pile-ups in Superbike history. Pitt  and Muggeridge got 
tangled up as  they left the  start line, causing widespread 
carnage. Wild card Julien Da  Costa hit Bussei, who was 
already on  the  deck, with Martin another unwilling 
faller. Bussei suffered concussion and  hurt his  neck and 
shoulder, Martin damaged his  kidney, with Muggeridge 
needing stitches in his head after his footpeg gouged its 
way into  and under his  helmet. Pitt  skinned his  hands 
but, like  Da  Costa, made it back for the  restart. No such 
drama at the  second time of asking as  Vermeulen and 
Lanzi battled for the  win, but then Chris's rear  sprocket 
broke, leaving the  young Italian to take an  unchallenged 
victory. Good friends off the  track, but  fierce opponents 
on  it, Kagayama and  Haga fought tooth and  nail  for 
second, with the  Suzuki rider taking the  honours 
ater the  Yamaha's tyres faded. It had  been a  long, 
hard season, but  one  of the  elder statesmen of World 
Superbike had  proved that, with the  right bike and  the 
right team, anything Is possible. 
‘During my years with Petronas, | never doubted my 
ability to win  another title,’ said Corser, ‘| knew that all | 
needed was the  right bike and  the  right team. For years 
I've  seen the  Alstare set-up in the  paddock and  always 
wanted to  ride  for  Francis Batta, so  when | got the  call, 
| didn't hesitate for a second. We  put in a lot of hard 
work before the  season began, did a lot of testing and  it 
paid off  big time.’

I ie Bayliss returned to  familiar territory in  2006 
after three years in  the  MotoGP wilderness and 
dominated the  championship from its  too  early start in 
Qatar, in  February, right the  way through to  its  autumn 
finish in  France. The veteran Aussie proved that his  time 
away from World Superbike had  honed rather than 
diminished his skills, and his  hunger to win  was as  strong 
as  ever. He  led  the  championship from the  first round 
and, despite a few  crashes along the  way, failed to  finish 
just twice all season. Only runner-up James Toseland on 
the  Ten  Kate Honda was more consistent but  his  three 
victories throughout the  year were dwarfed by Bayliss’s 
twelve wins, and Troy suitably wrapped up  the  title with 
one round to  go  at  Ducati’s home track, Imola. He  then 
crowned a  superb season by winning the  last  MotoGP 
race of the  year at Valencia to  show that Superbikers 
can  win  in MotoGPs. It had  been five  years since his first 
World Superbike title, but  once the  season got  into its 
Stride his  rivals knew that Bayliss would be  hard, if not 
impossible, to  stop. 
After the  fire  sale  that saw both Toseland and Regis 
Laconi thrown out  of the  official Ducati team at  the 
end of 2005, Bayliss was seen as  the  man to  reinstate 
the  Italian manufacturer's position at  the  top  of the 
Superbike pile and he  didn’t disappoint. Not  even a 
horrible wrist injury while doing a  spot of winter off- 
roading prevented the  Australian from starting the  new 
year in  aggressive mode right from the  first tests 
If the  injury caused any  discomfort or  pain it was 
never acknowledged, and at  the  end of a  gruelling day’s 
testing he would just  say, ‘| guess it gets a  bit  sore when 
I'm  done riding, but  it’s  no  problem really.’ 
Bayliss’s team-mate in  the  Xerox Ducati squad 
was the  young Italian hope Lorenzo Lanzi, having his 
first full  year as  a  factory rider, but  a  family tragedy 
got  his season off  to  a  slow start and  although he 
mustered two podiums at  Valencia, he  never looked like 
threatening the  rostrum again

Xerox Ducati were once more the  only real  factory 
team contesting the  nineteenth running of the 
championship, unless you  count Foggy Petronas —  and 
most people didn’t. The  main differences between the 
2006 FO6  Ducatis and  the  previous year’s models were 
the  electronics and  suspension. Bayliss and Lanzi had  the 
benefit of the  superbly working Magneti Marelli traction 
control system with Ohlins TTX20 upside-down forks 
and  TTX36 rear  shocks. Their traction control was  far 
better than any  rival  offerings and  allowed Bayliss and 
Lanzi to  get away with things the  rest  could only dream 
about. 
Ducati’s B teams consisted of Team Berik Sterilgarda, 
with the  experienced Ruben Xaus partnered by Marco 
Borciani, and  Ducati SC  Caracchi with affable ex-GP 
rider Robby Rolfo on  board. It’s  hard to  know in which 
category to  put Pedercini’s Ducatis, as  they were running 
999RS machines which many considered well past their 
sell-by date. They started the  season with a three-rider 
line-up of Lucio Pedercini, lvan Clementi and  young 
German hopeful Max Neukirchner, but  after yet another 
crash due  to technical problems on  the  outdated bikes 
Max decided that he’d had  enough, limping away before 
doing any  serious damage to  himself. 
When Ducati got rid  of Toseland, their 2004 World 
Champion, James found himself in an  awkward position. 
He was entertaining all and  sundry at the  piano in a  hotel 
bar  in Imola after the  last  race  of 2005 but  had  no  ride 
lined up for 2006, so  when Ten Kate Honda threw him 
a  lifeline he grabbed it eagerly. The  previous incumbent, 
Chris Vermeulen, had  departed to the  perceived holy 
grail of MotoGP and  the  Dutch outfit were looking for 
a title  contender to  partner Aussie Karl  Muggeridge. 
Toseland, and  all the  Honda riders, struggled with a 
traction control system far inferior to those of Ducati, 
Suzuki and  Yamaha (as witnessed by James's regular 
tyre-smoking antics) and it is greatly to  his credit that he 
was able to finish the  season in second spot. 
Pierfrancesco Chili was riding for  DFX Treme Honda 
in what would be his swan-song season, together 
with his young pupil, Michel Fabrizio. There was also 
another Honda team of note —  Klaffi Honda —  and  the 
German outfit had  signed MotoGP star  Alex Barros. 
The  Brazilian was obviously a class act,  but  his generally 
poor performances in qualifying usually left  him  with too 
much work to  do come race day.

victory ahead of Toseland and  Barros. Alex had  been

scrambled to  the  safety of the  trackside before realising 
the  force of the  impact. The  footage was  so  dramatic 
it even made national TV  news and  featured in all the 
press coverage of the  event.

If a  Ducati rider is going to win  a  championship then 
there is  no  better place than at  their home track, Imola. 
Bayliss didn’t need to win  or  do anything spectacular 
to  take the  title, and  his cruise round the  4.959-km 
circuit to  fifth place in  Race 1 was all that was required 
to  send the  Ducati fans into  a frenzy of flag-waving 
and  celebration. Barros was in  eighth at  the  end  of 
the  first lap of Race 1 and  then had  to  keep clear of 
crashes before starting his charge. This was to  be the 
Brazillan’s day. He  rode with all the  poise and experience 
of his GP  days to  take his  first-ever World Superbike 
victory and become the  eighth different winner of the 
season. Second was Toseland, with Pitt  and  Haga third 
and  fourth. By the  time Bayliss returned to  the  pit lane 
after his cool-down lap he was already wearing a  2007 
World Champion T-shirt, but  if anybody thought he'd 
be  resting on  his  laurels in  the  second race they were to 
be  disappointed. With all the  pressure off,  he stormed 
to  his eleventh win of the  season, with Barros a  superb 
second and Kagayama third. Pitt  took fourth ahead of 
Toseland, with Haga an  indifferent sixth. And what of 
the  outgoing champion? Another depressing afternoon 
for  Corser saw him retire in  Race 1 —  he  said his  gearbox 
was finding false neutrals —  and struggle to  seventh in 
the  second race as  a  result of a  spinning rear  tyre. He
