in perfect harmony and recorded their first win. 
The increased grid saw the  return of Ben Bostrom, 
who replaced Haga in the  Renegade team (now on 
CBR1000RR Hondas) from the  year before. It was a 
frustratingly mixed season of crashes and  few highlights 
for the  American, due  to the  unreliability of the  bikes 
and behind-the-scenes squabbles. Also Honda-mounted 
was the  oldest racer in the  field, Pierfrancesco Chili, and 
the  youngest, Max Neukirchner, both riding for Team 
Klaffi Honda. Like  Team Renegade (and many others) 
they'd spend most of the  year trying to  improve their 
bikes. Yamaha Motor France entered the  fray with 
former GP  winner Norick Abe and  Sébastien Gimbert, 
and two other ex-GP riders —  Fonsi Nieto (partnered 
by rising Italian Lorenzo Lanzi) in Team Ducati SC 
Caracchi and fellow-Spaniard José Luis  Cardoso (Yamaha 
DFXtreme) —  also  joined the  Superbike club. 
So  a  new era  for World Superbikes and a  new track 
for the  first race of the  year: Losail, Qatar. The  facility 
was brand new and had  everything a  modern race track 
could offer; the  only thing missing was the  fans. Not 
that Corser and team-mate Kagayama noticed, for  each 
took a win and a  podium to  give Alstare Suzuki a  dream 
start and leave the  rest of the  pack worried. It was the 
first time in  the  history of the  series that Suzuki had 
scored a  double and, ominously, looked like  it wouldn't 
be the  last. Troy’s win in  Race 1 came after an  unusual 
occurrence in  the  desert: rain! The race started dry, 
but  when rain  began to  fall  after ten  laps, and Laconi 
crashed as  the  conditions worsened, it was red-flagged.

Kagayama won the  second part ‘on  the  road’, but 
Corser had  stuck close by in  second and  took the  overall 
win, with Laconi third. New boy Pitt  took fourth, with 
team-mate Haga fifth and  2004 champion Toseland 
sixth. In the  second race, a  too-hard rear  tyre cost 
Corser the  double and  he  had  to settle for third, but  at 
least team-mate Kagayama won, with Laconi second. 
Eight riders began the  battle for fourth, with Vermeulen 
taking the  honours ahead of Chili and  Toseland —  not  an 
auspicious start for the  former GP  stars, with Abe's pair 
of top tens the  best of the  bunch. It was, however, a  lot 
better than Petronas, who managed just a  single point 
between them. 
If ever a  rider was made for  Phillip Island, that rider 
was Troy Corser —  especially when he  had  the  right 
tool for the job. He  and  the  GSX-R1000 had  topped 
the  tests there and  should have led  the  charge in 
qualifying, but  he found himself way down the  pecking 
order after Superpole —  even behind the  Petronas. Chili 
was a  non-starter, thanks to  a  broken collarbone, and 
the  new 1000cc four-cylinder bikes were surprisingly 
outgunned (in top  speed anyway) by Laconi’s Ducati, 
which burst through the  speed trap at a  staggering 
318km/h (197.6mph). Only 16  riders finished Race 1, 
due  to crashes and  other DNFs, with Corser taking 
the win, eight seconds ahead of team-mate (and 
Superpole winner), Kagayama. Vermeulen used his  local 
knowledge to take third, but  only after a  battle with 
rookie Neukirchner, which saw both paint and rubber 
traded. The  good news for the  start of Race 2 was that 
the  wind had  died down; the  bad  news was rain  after 
12  laps, which caused the  red  flag to come out. And 
so,  for the  second time in two rounds, another two- 
parter. Conditions were tricky to  say  the  least, and  there 
were numerous fallers, notably at the  Hayshed, where 
Walker, Pitt  and Haga all succumbed. Laconi managed a 
spectacular ‘save’ there, only to fall  further up  the  hill  at 
Lukey Heights. He  restarted and  took seventh place in a 
race that saw only 14 finishers. Corser kept his  head to  . 
take his second win  of the  day, with Kagayama second 
and Neukirchner a  superb third. 
The  Corser roadshow continued its  momentum at 
Valencia, with yet another double for the  Alstare rider, 
but  the  big surprise of the  weekend was that none of 
the  Ducatis really featured on  a track that’s normally 
their kind of territory. The  best they could manage was 
Toseland’s ninth in the  first  race and  no  Ducati (factory 
Or  private) even got  a  point in the  second —  a  big change 
from the  year before when they practically filled the 
top  ten. Honda was Suzuki's main challenger, with 
Vermeulen taking a  pair of runner-up spots. Kagayama 
was third in  Race 1 and  Walker third on  the  Kawasaki 
in  Race 2, leaving only Yamaha without a  podium 
place so  far.  Laconi didn’t even get to  the  start line: a 
heavy fall  in  qualifying left  him  with concussion and  the 
doctors wisely ruled him  out. Neukirchner was back in 
the  news again, this  time for different reasons, when 
he suffered the  biggest highside of the  year in  the  first 
race, his sliding Honda taking out  Lanzi before pushing 
Muggeridge off  track. The  Italian broke his  collarbone,

Monza’s fast  track makes for fast  racing, and  should 
really have favoured the  1000cc fours, bur  Bologna’s 
finest showed a  huge improvement after their sluggish 
start and were competitive again. It wasn’t quite 
enough to  stop Corser racking up win number six  out 
of seven starts, but  they did  take two podiums. As 
usual, the  Italian circuit served a feast of high-speed 
action, with the  opening race ending with just 1.75s 
covering the  top  four. Kagayama played wingman to 
Corser, with Toseland third and Laconi fourth. The Ten 
Kate Hondas should have been challengers but, for 
some unaccountable reason, the  team decided not  to 
use  the  special ‘Monza’ motors in  Race 1. The plan 
failed for Vermeulen when his  CBR1000RR ground to  an 
undignified halt  after only a  lap.  In  Race 2, the  ‘Monza’ 
motor went in and  Vermeulen stole the  win, a  mere 
half-second ahead of Laconi. Corser took third, after 
complaining about brake problems, ahead of Toseland 
and  Pitt.  There had  been eight riders contesting the 
lead at one  stage of the  race, conclusive proof that you 
don't need the  fastest bike to  have a  good result at a 
fast  track. 
The  season took an  unpredictable turn at  Silverstone 
when Laconi and  Toseland gave Ducati a win  apiece. 
Normally the  Northants track is suited to the  high-speed 
fours, despite the  mickey-mouse chicane just before the 
start-finish straight, but the  use  of the  so-called shorter 
‘International’ circuit negated much of the  1000cc bikes’ 
advantage. There was universal disapproval, from riders 
and  teams alike, especially as  the  information about 
which circuit was to  be  used was only discovered a 
week or  so  before the  event. Nevertheless, the  racing 
was exciting, the  result unexpected and  the  crowd 
enjoyed Toseland taking a win  on  home soil. James was 
also in contention in the  first race, but  that was won by 
team-mate Laconi, with Corser second. However, a win 
and a third for  Ducati was a  huge turnaround, and  a 
great relief to  Ducatisti everywhere. Corser led  most of 
the  second race until overtaken by Toseland, then settled 
for  runner-up spot after Laconi crashed out  and Haga 
wasn’t close enough to  cause any  problems, knowing 
he’d increased his championship lead over his  nearest 
rival —  team-mate Kagayama. 
Misano returned to  its traditional summer slot, 
much to  everybody’s relief, except perhaps Pirelli: track 
temperatures were in the  fifties on  race day. Ducati’s 
recent testing programme (riders and tyres) reaped 
dividends, with Laconi winning both races. Vermeulen 
took a  pair  of seconds, Corser a  pair of thirds and  the 
symmetry even extended to Toseland’ s pair  of fourths. 
Although the  top  four may have been the  same in  both 
24-lap races, they were very different kettles of fish. 
Laconi ran  away with Race 1, four seconds in  front of 
Vermeulen, with Corser a further four seconds adrift; 
Race 2 was a  much closer affair. And Kagayama lost  his 
second place in  the  championship. He’d been fined for a 
fist  fight with Spaniard Cardoso in  qualifying and maybe 
the  red  mist hadn't cleared in  time for  race day. A crash

the-scenes work testing for the  Suzuka 8 Hour was cited 
as  a factor in his  loss  of form and, true or  not, it would 
be the  last  race of the  year before he saw the  podium 
again. 
It had  been nine years since the  Superbike circus 
had  been to  Brno, a  long-time favourite with fans, and 
this  year’s race saw ‘Nitro-Nori’ Haga break his and 
Yamaha's winning duck. His  previous best result so  far 
had  been a third at Silverstone, but  his  performance 
in Race 2 was nothing short of sensational and  even 
outclassed series leader Corser. Troy had  been without 
a win  since Monza and  many observers were beginning . 
to  think that, once again, the  wheels were beginning 
to  come off the  Aussie’s wagon. Not  this  time. He 
dominated practice, and Superpole, and stormed his 
way to victory In Race 1, finishing over six seconds ahead 
of Toseland, with Laconi third and  Walker fourth. He 
was on  course for another double, but  he’d reckoned 
without Haga. The  Japanese rider hadn't even qualified 
for  Superpole and his  18th position on  the  grid meant 
he had  to  do  something really special. Nobody had  ever 
won a  Superbike race from outside the  top  16  before, 
but  Haga didn’t care about statistics. Lap after lap he 
charged though the  field, at  record pace, forcing his way 
through gaps that didn’t exist until nobody was in front. 
Those fortunate enough to witness it will  never forget 
it—  and  that probably includes runner-up Corser, third- 
placed Vermeulen and the  rest  of the  riders who saw a 
flash of blue and  white go  past. 
As  usual the  biggest race on  the  World Superbike 
calendar was Brands Hatch and, as  ever, the  on-track 
action didn’t disappoint the  massed crowds. Haga, 
fresh from his victory in Brno, was the  only rider to  give

to each other like  glue throughout the  25-lapper, with 
the  lead changing hands no  less  than seven times, but 
in the  end  Troy just sneaked it, by less  than two-tenths

and  crowd favourite Walker fifth. Toseland DNFd with 
an  ‘electrical problem’, much to the  dismay of his  legions 
of fans looking for  a home win  for the  number-one 
plate-holder. If Race 1 was a  Corser/Haga thriller, Race 
2 was even more of the  same —  if that were possible! 
With nearest title  rival  Vermeulen finishing only fourth in 
the  first  Troy didn’t need to win, but  that didn’t prevent 
him  pulling out  all the  stops and  giving Nori a  helluva 
fight. For  virtually every lap there was hardly daylight 
between them. They tangled on  the  back part of the 
4.197-km circuit —  far from the  eyes of the  crowd, but 
visible on  the  big-screen monitors —  with Corser running 
off-track. He  got  back on  course but  that excursion into 
the  dirt  gave Haga just the  gap he  needed to  take the 
chequered flag. Vermeulen was third, a  long way down, 
with Walker netting his second fourth place of the 
day. Two fantastic races with the  top four in each race 
different manufacturers —  what more could the  series 
ask  for? 
If Vermeulen needed to  reassert himself, Assen was 
a  good place to  do  it.  His  Ten  Kate team’s headquarters 
were just down the  road and  hordes of home fans were 
ready and willing to  provide vocal support. Like Brands, 
Assen is  another great Superbike venue and  although 
the  circuit had  been remodelled there was still  enough 
of the  ‘old’ Assen to  please riders and  fans. The  racing 
was top  notch, too, with the  track still  favouring the 
best and  fastest riders. Vermeulen started his campaign 
well, by taking Superpole, and  then fastest lap in  Race 1, 
a  record that will  last  forever as  it would be the  last  year 
of the  North Loop. Four riders disputed the  lead until

Chris decided it was going to  be  his  race, leaving behind 
a frenetic battle between Haga, Corser and  Toseland, 
with James taking second and  Nori third. Corser was 
fourth —  the first  time he’d not  been on  the  podium all 
year. Race 2 was a straight three-way fight: Vermeulen, 
Haga, Toseland. All three led  several times, but the 
young Aussie just held off  Haga out  of the  final chicane 
to take the flag by 0.85s. Toseland was  third, Corser 
off the  podium again in fourth. A crisis? Maybe. But  at 
least he was  better off than Laconi. The  Frenchman had 
crashed in qualifying, injuring the tendons in his elbow, 
removing skin  from his arm  as  he made contact with 
first  the tarmac and  then his bike. It was  the  second 
time this year he’d been forced to  miss races after a 
practice crash. 
Throughout the  season young Italian Lorenzo Lanzi 
had been doing well on  the  SC  Caracchi Ducati, and 
when the  factory Xerox Ducati team looked for a 
replacement for Laconi at Lausitz the  choice was simple 
but obvious. Lanzi took his chance right from the  start 
of practice and  surprised even the  Ducati top  brass by 
winning Superpole. Could he go on  to take victory as 
well? Championship leader Corser’s non-podium finishes 
in Assen had  given his nearest challenger, Vermeulen, 
a glimmer of hope and  the  deficit was now down to 
86  points —  still  a good lead, but  not  an  impossible 
target. Lanzi got overexcited at the  start of Race 1 and 
completely lost  his Superpole advantage by going into 
the first  turn too  hot. He  had  to take to the  slip road 
and, by the  time he  recovered, he was in the  middle of 
the  pack. Vermeulen kept up  his winning streak, making 
it three in a  row, with Haga second and  Corser third, in 
a  race halted by rain  on  lap 20  out  of 24. Maybe seeing 
his young countryman on  the  up was  what prompted 
Corser to  push so  hard in Race 2. Too  hard as  it turned 
out, as  he lost the front going into  Turn 1 and  crashed. 
Troy picked up the  bike and  got going again, dead last, 
but  rode the wheels off his Suzuki to take 13th place. 
At the  sharp end  Lanzi showed that his qualifying and 
Superpole form had  been no  fluke, controlling the  race 
and  running out  the winner 0.84s ahead of Vermeulen, 
with Haga third. Kagayama’s fifth and  fourth confirmed 
he'd now completely recovered from his trips to and 
from Japan on  Suzuka 8 Hour duties. 
Laconi was deemed fit for  Imola, so  Lausitz hero 
Lanzi moved back to the  SC  Caracchi squad, though this 
time he had  factory engines to  play with. A large part 
of the  crowd had  come to see  the  young Italian and 
even the wet  conditions didn’t put them off,  but they 
were destined to  leave the  old  circuit feeling robbed. 
A rainstorm of biblical proportions flooded the track 
after Race 1, causing deep puddles round the 4.933-km 
circuit. The drains did  their best, but  lakes of standing 
water and  small rivers running across the  track caused 
the  top  riders to stop the  second race’s proceedings 
before they started. The  start was delayed, then delayed 
further, and  finally Corser, Vermeulen and  Laconi went 
out  in pace cars  to take a closer look. They confirmed 
what everybody feared, but  it was Race Control who 
made the  decision to cancel Race 2.  The  decision 
also meant that Corser was World Champion, for the 
second time, depriving Vermeulen of the  chance to 
take the  fight to the  last  round in Magny-Cours. All  this 
overshadowed events in Race 1, where Vermeulen had 
taken victory in difficult conditions. The  race started 
wet, then the  track began to dry out  as  he and  Corser 
sought to  master both each other and  the  conditions. 
At  the end  there was only 0.297s between them, with 
Haga a  distant third, Toseland fourth, Martin fifth and 
Walker sixth. Six different manufacturers in the  top six 
was a vindication of FGSport’s decision to  go with the 
one-make tyre rule; it was  just a shame that the  rain 
came down and  decided everything. 
There was still  plenty to fight for at  Magny-Cours 
—  apart from first and  second places in the  standings 
—  and  even new champ Corser and  Vermeulen wanted 
to end  the  season on a high. Troy was  taken out  of the 
equation early on  with a  disastrous Superpole, through 
no  fault of his own. Unknown to  him, at least until 
the  first turn or  so,  a team member had  over-inflated 
his  rear  tyre by a substantial margin and he spent the 
whole lap slipping and  sliding around the  track with 
clouds of smoke coming from his  rear  tyre. Entertaining 
to watch, but  an  unsatisfactory 16th-quickest lap time 
and  a fourth-row start as  a  result, so  it’s to  his credit 
he still  found the  hunger to fight his way up to fifth in 
the first race and  an  even better fourth in the  second. 
Vermeulen continued his run  of good form by leading 
from the  start of Race 1 and  was  never headed on  his 
way to  a comfortable eight-second victory. Kagayama 
took second with Toseland third and  Muggeridge 
fourth, not  far ahead of the  charging Corser. The  start 
of Race 2 witnessed one  of the  most dramatic first-lap 
pile-ups in Superbike history. Pitt  and Muggeridge got 
tangled up as  they left the  start line, causing widespread 
carnage. Wild card Julien Da  Costa hit Bussei, who was 
already on  the  deck, with Martin another unwilling 
faller. Bussei suffered concussion and  hurt his  neck and 
shoulder, Martin damaged his  kidney, with Muggeridge 
needing stitches in his head after his footpeg gouged its 
way into  and under his  helmet. Pitt  skinned his  hands 
but, like  Da  Costa, made it back for the  restart. No such 
drama at the  second time of asking as  Vermeulen and 
Lanzi battled for the  win, but then Chris's rear  sprocket 
broke, leaving the  young Italian to take an  unchallenged 
victory. Good friends off the  track, but  fierce opponents 
on  it, Kagayama and  Haga fought tooth and  nail  for 
second, with the  Suzuki rider taking the  honours 
ater the  Yamaha's tyres faded. It had  been a  long, 
hard season, but  one  of the  elder statesmen of World 
Superbike had  proved that, with the  right bike and  the 
right team, anything Is possible. 
‘During my years with Petronas, | never doubted my 
ability to win  another title,’ said Corser, ‘| knew that all | 
needed was the  right bike and  the  right team. For years 
I've  seen the  Alstare set-up in the  paddock and  always 
wanted to  ride  for  Francis Batta, so  when | got the  call, 
| didn't hesitate for a second. We  put in a lot of hard 
work before the  season began, did a lot of testing and  it 
paid off  big time.’

I ie Bayliss returned to  familiar territory in  2006 
after three years in  the  MotoGP wilderness and 
dominated the  championship from its  too  early start in 
Qatar, in  February, right the  way through to  its  autumn 
finish in  France. The veteran Aussie proved that his  time 
away from World Superbike had  honed rather than 
diminished his skills, and his  hunger to win  was as  strong 
as  ever. He  led  the  championship from the  first round 
and, despite a few  crashes along the  way, failed to  finish 
just twice all season. Only runner-up James Toseland on 
the  Ten  Kate Honda was more consistent but  his  three 
victories throughout the  year were dwarfed by Bayliss’s 
twelve wins, and Troy suitably wrapped up  the  title with 
one round to  go  at  Ducati’s home track, Imola. He  then 
crowned a  superb season by winning the  last  MotoGP 
race of the  year at Valencia to  show that Superbikers 
can  win  in MotoGPs. It had  been five  years since his first 
World Superbike title, but  once the  season got  into its 
Stride his  rivals knew that Bayliss would be  hard, if not 
impossible, to  stop. 
After the  fire  sale  that saw both Toseland and Regis 
Laconi thrown out  of the  official Ducati team at  the 
end of 2005, Bayliss was seen as  the  man to  reinstate 
the  Italian manufacturer's position at  the  top  of the 
Superbike pile and he  didn’t disappoint. Not  even a 
horrible wrist injury while doing a  spot of winter off- 
roading prevented the  Australian from starting the  new 
year in  aggressive mode right from the  first tests 
If the  injury caused any  discomfort or  pain it was 
never acknowledged, and at  the  end of a  gruelling day’s 
testing he would just  say, ‘| guess it gets a  bit  sore when 
I'm  done riding, but  it’s  no  problem really.’ 
Bayliss’s team-mate in  the  Xerox Ducati squad 
was the  young Italian hope Lorenzo Lanzi, having his 
first full  year as  a  factory rider, but  a  family tragedy 
got  his season off  to  a  slow start and  although he 
mustered two podiums at  Valencia, he  never looked like 
threatening the  rostrum again

Xerox Ducati were once more the  only real  factory 
team contesting the  nineteenth running of the 
championship, unless you  count Foggy Petronas —  and 
most people didn’t. The  main differences between the 
2006 FO6  Ducatis and  the  previous year’s models were 
the  electronics and  suspension. Bayliss and Lanzi had  the 
benefit of the  superbly working Magneti Marelli traction 
control system with Ohlins TTX20 upside-down forks 
and  TTX36 rear  shocks. Their traction control was  far 
better than any  rival  offerings and  allowed Bayliss and 
Lanzi to  get away with things the  rest  could only dream 
about. 
Ducati’s B teams consisted of Team Berik Sterilgarda, 
with the  experienced Ruben Xaus partnered by Marco 
Borciani, and  Ducati SC  Caracchi with affable ex-GP 
rider Robby Rolfo on  board. It’s  hard to  know in which 
category to  put Pedercini’s Ducatis, as  they were running 
999RS machines which many considered well past their 
sell-by date. They started the  season with a three-rider 
line-up of Lucio Pedercini, lvan Clementi and  young 
German hopeful Max Neukirchner, but  after yet another 
crash due  to technical problems on  the  outdated bikes 
Max decided that he’d had  enough, limping away before 
doing any  serious damage to  himself. 
When Ducati got rid  of Toseland, their 2004 World 
Champion, James found himself in an  awkward position. 
He was entertaining all and  sundry at the  piano in a  hotel 
bar  in Imola after the  last  race  of 2005 but  had  no  ride 
lined up for 2006, so  when Ten Kate Honda threw him 
a  lifeline he grabbed it eagerly. The  previous incumbent, 
Chris Vermeulen, had  departed to the  perceived holy 
grail of MotoGP and  the  Dutch outfit were looking for 
a title  contender to  partner Aussie Karl  Muggeridge. 
Toseland, and  all the  Honda riders, struggled with a 
traction control system far inferior to those of Ducati, 
Suzuki and  Yamaha (as witnessed by James's regular 
tyre-smoking antics) and it is greatly to  his credit that he 
was able to finish the  season in second spot. 
Pierfrancesco Chili was riding for  DFX Treme Honda 
in what would be his swan-song season, together 
with his young pupil, Michel Fabrizio. There was also 
another Honda team of note —  Klaffi Honda —  and  the 
German outfit had  signed MotoGP star  Alex Barros. 
The  Brazilian was obviously a class act,  but  his generally 
poor performances in qualifying usually left  him  with too 
much work to  do come race day.

and  was a straight fight between Aussies Corser and 
Bayliss. The  Suzuki man took the  win  by just over a

As expected, Aussie riders ruled the  roost at  Phillip 
Island, with the  two Troys taking a win apiece. Bayliss 
had  been in scorching form from the  start of practice 
and led  the  opening race by a country mile, but  then his 
too  soft  tyre  started going off at  half-distance, allowing 
the  rest  to catch up.  Corser took the  lead, with six  laps 
to  go,  and  then the  win, less  than half  a  second off 
Barros, with Toseland third. Haga was fourth, with Rolfo 
fifth and a slipping and  sliding Bayliss sixth. In  Race 2 
Bayliss fitted a  harder tyre and patiently waited until 
the  pace up  front slowed. He  chose his  moment well, 
charged into  the  lead and  stormed to  a comfortable 
victory ahead of Toseland and  Barros. Alex had  been 
part of a  drama early in  the  race when he  had  hit the 
fallen Corser on  the  exit  of MG  corner. The  big screens 
showed Corser on  the  floor and  then Barros’s Honda 
running over the  Australian's neck and  head. It looked 
horrible in the  slow-motion replays, but  somehow Troy 
scrambled to  the  safety of the  trackside before realising 
the  force of the  impact. The  footage was  so  dramatic 
it even made national TV  news and  featured in all the 
press coverage of the  event.

form in qualifying and  Superpole. Pre-season testing 
at  the  tight and  twisty track had  been dominated by 
Bayliss, so  Corser’s form was something of a  surprise,

Toseland was on  pole at  Misano, his  first since 2003, 
and he and  the  other main contenders desperately 
needed to  peg  back Bayliss’s run  of success. Troy, 
however, defied his seventh place on  the  grid to  notch 
up  his eighth win  on  the  trot, a  massive seven seconds 
ahead of the  rest  of the  field. Toseland was second, with 
Kagayama third, his  best result to  date. Another rider 
to  score well was Pitt  in Race 2, the  Aussie taking his 
maiden World Superbike victory with Barros second and 
team-mate Haga third. Bayliss had  crashed on  lap  17  but 
showed his  ‘never say  die’  spirit by remounting to  finish 
12th. He wasn’t to  know that it wouldn’t matter by the 
back end  of the  season; it was just typical Bayliss. It was 
another day of disappointment for  Corser, with a fall  in 
Race 1 (when his  bike jumped out  of gear) and  another 
crash while leading Race 2 after trying to  avoid cement 
dust. Nil  points meant a  drop to fourth in the  standings 
and  the  disappearance of any  hope of retaining his title. 
Haga’s Superpole at  Brno was only his third in  170 
Starts and  should have put  him  in good stead for  a 
victory or  two at the  Czech circuit, but  instead it was 
another Japanese rider who stole the  glory with a  pair 
of faultless wins. Kagayama’s podium at the  previous 
round had  been just the  confidence boost he needed 
and  that, together with a  productive test  at  Brno one 
month earlier, allowed him to  take two comfortable 
victories. Toseland had  to  settle for second in Race 1, 
after leading the  charge early on,  with Fabrizio third. 
Kagayama’s screaming start in the  second race left  the 
rest  trailing and  the  main battle for the  minor podium 
places was between Haga, Corser and  Fabrizio. Michel 
had  only qualified 12th, but  there was something about 
Brno that suited the  young Roman and  an  even better 
result was in store. He  went into  the  final chicane in 
fourth place, then pulled out  an  audacious move, block 
passed Corser, pushed Haga wide and  emerged ahead 
of his two vastly more experienced rivals. At the  flag 
the  trio  were separated by less  than 0.083s, with Haga 
taking third. The  Japanese rider and  the  Aussie were 
united, though, in  their comments about the  Italian’s 
antics: ‘What he did  was plain crazy. He  could've taken 
all three of us  out  there!’ Troy Corser had  missed the 
Brno test  after his son  had  kindly given him  chicken pox, 
but  his fifth and  fourth showed that he was getting 
back to form.

riders, loomed large next. Brands Hatch’s natural setting, 
with the  crowds close to  the  action, witnessed Bayliss 
and Lanzi wearing Superman-style leathers on  race day. 
The rest of the  field could have used some Kryptonite 
in the  first race as  the  Aussie got  back to winning ways, 
giving Ducati its  250th victory in  World Superbike.

and Pitt  fourth. Race 2 saw Haga’s well-overdue first

If a  Ducati rider is going to win  a  championship then 
there is  no  better place than at  their home track, Imola. 
Bayliss didn’t need to win  or  do anything spectacular 
to  take the  title, and  his cruise round the  4.959-km 
circuit to  fifth place in  Race 1 was all that was required 
to  send the  Ducati fans into  a frenzy of flag-waving 
and  celebration. Barros was in  eighth at  the  end  of 
the  first lap of Race 1 and  then had  to  keep clear of 
crashes before starting his charge. This was to  be the 
Brazillan’s day. He  rode with all the  poise and experience 
of his GP  days to  take his  first-ever World Superbike 
victory and become the  eighth different winner of the 
season. Second was Toseland, with Pitt  and  Haga third 
and  fourth. By the  time Bayliss returned to  the  pit lane 
after his cool-down lap he was already wearing a  2007 
World Champion T-shirt, but  if anybody thought he'd 
be  resting on  his  laurels in  the  second race they were to 
be  disappointed. With all the  pressure off,  he stormed 
to  his eleventh win of the  season, with Barros a  superb 
second and Kagayama third. Pitt  took fourth ahead of 
Toseland, with Haga an  indifferent sixth. And what of 
the  outgoing champion? Another depressing afternoon 
for  Corser saw him retire in  Race 1 —  he  said his  gearbox 
was finding false neutrals —  and struggle to  seventh in 
the  second race as  a  result of a  spinning rear  tyre. He

—  enough for  the  Briton to  secure runner-up spot in

had  traded paint several times throughout the  race, a

he  2007 season was a  vintage year for  World 
Superbikes and a truly fitting way for  it to  celebrate 
its  20th year. The  racing was consistently of the  highest 
order and the  result in  doubt until the  very last  race, 
with any  one of three riders in  contention for  the  title 
But, in  the  end, Briton James Toseland once again 
overcame all obstacles to  take the  title  in  a  nail-biting 
finale at  Magny-Cours —  the  scene of his  previous title 
victory in  2004 
During 2007 some questioned what they saw as 
an  ‘over-aggressive’ riding style, but  James ignored all 
his  critics and had  the  strength to  recover from a blip 
in  fortunes, after a  stunning double at  Brands Hatch, 
and return focused on  the  job in  hand. In  so  doing he 
became only the  second rider in  World Superbike history 
to win the  title with two different manufacturers, the 
other being Troy Corser in  1996 and 2005 
Even before the  season began the  series had  received 
a  massive boost in  profile with the  arrival of four-times 
250cc GP  champion and former MotoGP star Max 
Biaggi. For  FGSport, the  Rome-based organisers of the 
championship, Biaggi’s arrival was regarded as  a  huge 
coup as  not  only had the  series acquired one of road 
racing's biggest stars, but  it also meant they could stage 
a  race at  Vallelunga circuit, close to  their headquarters 
Rome Is  also Biaggi’s home town. Max's presence 
would mean a  considerable increase in  media coverage 
—  especially in  Italy —  and maybe, just maybe, the  first- 
ever Italian World Superbike Champion 
The ‘Roman Emperor’, as  he  is  known to  his 
legions of  fans, arrived on  the  scene with his  own 
entourage —  something not  hitherto seen in  World 
Superbikes —  and a  perhaps over-fastidious MotoGP 
approach. It was something Alstare Suzuki tried to 
accommodate from the very first test session, but 
it would be  Biaggi’s demeanour that would prove a 
sterner test of  his  team’s warm and friendly atmosphere 
throughout the  year. Biaggi had replaced 2005

spacious press room was unusually full, thanks to 
scores of Italian media who had  come to  see  if Biaggi 
could adapt to  World Superbikes —  and  they must have

won the  opening race. It’s  true that Max had  raced 
there in MotoGP, but  his  rookie win  was greeted with 
huge delight by them, and  the  Italian series organisers. 
Toseland took second, with Lanzi a somewhat suprising 
third, but  James got the  better of Biaggi in  Race 2, 
with Corser third, ahead of team-mate Haga. Reigning 
champion Troy Bayliss struggled with tyre problems 
and  finished fifth and  eighth. At the  press conference

old  dogs, who want to  bite! | think Superbike is 
more challenging because you  don’t have the  best of

what you've got.’ He  left  as  joint championship leader 
with Toseland and  headed to  another circuit he  knew 
well —  Phillip Island. 
It’s  not  hard to see  why riders and  fans love Phillip

virtually unmatched at any  other track and  once again the 
racing lived up to  its reputation. Both 22-lappers featured 
superb battles between local hero and  champion Bayliss 
and  title  contender Toseland. Such was  the  intensity of 
their fight they sometimes traded paint, but  neither had 
any  complaints afterwards. Bayliss delighted the  home 
fans by taking victory in the  first  race, with Toseland

The  Assen round normally takes place in September, 
but  this  year the  event was switched to April. Well- 
prepared Assen fans always turn up for  races with 
waterproofs —  they certainly came in handy in 2006 
—  but  the  weather gods were in a good mood for 
Round 5 and  the  rainwear stayed packed away on  race 
day. Toseland won the  first race by a  hair  from Haga, 
with Xaus third. The  second race then witnessed one 
of the  greatest battles in World Superbike history, with 
Toseland and  Bayliss wheel to wheel for almost the 
entire distance. It came down to the  final turn, Bayliss 
getting through an  impossible gap  and  taking the  win 
by just 0.009s. Biaggi was a  long way back in third but 
still  second in the  championship, as  he  had  been since 
the  second round. 
A huge number of fans came to  Monza, the  first of 
the  three scheduled Italian rounds, and many of them 
packed the  paddock to  try and get an  autograph or 
photo with their hero, Max Biaggi. His  team had  to  hire 
three beefy security guards to  ensure his safe passage 
from pits to  hospitality or  motorhome. The  crowd

woods, as  he took victory by well over eight seconds

second was more of a  brisk hike, though the  margin

Toseland, Bayliss, Rolfo and  Biaggi were all  in contention 
for the  runner-up spot until the  final lap when Troy and 
Max clashed with each other at the  exit  of Ascari. Biaggi 
had  run  wide and  collided with Bayliss when he  rejoined 
the  track, the  impact bending the  Suzuki's clutch lever 
out  of position so  the  clutch didn’t work when he tried 
to  slow down for the  Parabolica. Biaggi was forced to 
stamp on  the  rear brake to  try and reduce his speed 
and in doing that ran  onto the  kerbstones and nearly 
crashed. By then Toseland, Rolfo and  Bayliss were gone. 
Rolfo was ready to  take his first podium of the  year, but 
with the  line  almost in sight his  Honda ran  out  of fuel, 
leaving Bayliss to  inherit third. 
Early on  race day Silverstone was hit  by heavy rain, 
then by an  absolute deluge and  Race 1 took place in 
soaking wet conditions that had  most of the  21  two- 
wheeled gladiators slipping, sliding and  crashing. In the 
end  only 13  got to the  finish line, and  one  of those, 
Toseland had  crashed, remounted and  was rewarded for 
his efforts by an  eighth place and  eight valuable points. 
He  certainly wasn’t to  know at the  time quite how 
valuable they would prove to  be!  Reigning champion 
Bayliss kept his  head and  somehow brought his  FO7 
Ducati home in  one piece to take the  chequered flag, 
two seconds ahead of Haga, with Corser filling the  final 
podium spot. There was then a  massive gap  of over 
45  seconds before Rolfo in  fourth ahead of Laconi and 
Biaggi. Before the  scheduled start of the  second race a 
track inspection was made by officials and  a few  of the

top  riders, but  when the  cars started aquaplaning on  the 
rain-sodden surface it was decided to  delay proceedings 
in  the  hope that conditions would improve. They never 
did,  and  the  race was cancelled, much to  the  disgust of 
the  considerable crowd who had  endured the  elements 
throughout the  day. 
After the  miserable conditions at  Silverstone it was 
a  relief and pleasure to  be  beside the  Adriatic seaside 
for  Misano, but  since World Superbikes raced there last 
season the  race track had been drastically altered and. 
Was now running in completely the  opposite direction. 
Ostensibly this  was done on  safety grounds, instigated 
because of the  circuit’s wish to  have a MotoGP race 
there, but  most of the  riders complained the  track was 
now more dangerous than before and certainly more 
bumpy. After practice Troy Corser said, ‘It’s  so  bumpy in 
some places that my  vision gets blurred and | just have 
to  point the  bike in  what | think is  in  the  right direction 
and hope for the  best!’ 
Misano is just up  the  road from Ducati’s Bologna 
headquarters so  it seemed almost inevitable that Bayliss 
would triumph —  and  Troy duly gave the  Ducatisti what 
they wanted, a  double victory. His  fellow-countryman 
Corser was runner-up in  Race 1, ahead of an  almost-fit- 
again Kagayama, with Toseland maintaining consistency 
with a  fourth place. MotoGP star Valentino Rossi was 
an  interested spectator and was in  exactly the  right 
place to  see  an  incident that probably cost Haga the 
championship in  that first race. Haga was in  front of 
Biaggi when the  Italian tried to  go  for  a  gap that simply

And so  to  Brands Hatch, good weather and  a 
huge crowd all wanting a  home win. They were not 
disappointed, for Toseland took a  remarkable double, 
with Corser second and  Biaggi third in the  first race. 
James's title aspirations were helped by two of his 
nearest rivals, Haga and  Bayliss, crashing out  and  he 
was full  of confidence for  Race 2, which saw a real 
dogfight between him  and  Haga for over three-quarters 
of the  race distance. In the  end, Haga had  to  concede 
victory to James, with the  margin of victory just over 
1.5  seconds. Corser took third, with Fabrizio fourth 
and Kagayama fifth despite being in pain from a  heavy 
crash in the  first  race. Toseland’s double was his first 
in World Superbike and  he was so  happy that, on  the 
cooling-down lap,  he stopped on  the front straight, 
stripped off  his  leathers and  then hurled them into  the 
crowd. He  left  Brands Hatch with a  66-point lead in 
the  series over his  nearest rival, Haga, with Biaggi close 
by in third. Bayliss was now nearly a  hundred points 
adrift of Toseland, something nobody would have 
thought possible at the  start of the  year. With three 
rounds remaining the  Briton had  one strong hand on 
the  trophy, but  Haga and  Biaggi were not  giving up the 
chase yet. 
It’s  hard to find beauty in the  monolith that is the 
Eurospeedway Lausitz, and not  easy to  believe it’s  a 
place for good racing. The  crowd, trapped as  they are 
in the  only place they can  go,  have a  reasonable view 
of the  track action, but  the  complex is so  vast that it 
only really comes to  life  if there over 100,000 spectators 
there. No  such luck for World Superbikes, whose 
weekend crowd figure of 49,000 looked respectable 
rather than remarkable. Haga won Race 1 by 11  seconds 
after Bayliss's tyre faded. Biaggi took advantage to  take 
second place, with Corser third. Series leader Toseland 
suffered a swinging-arm problem, but  instead of pulling 
out  he  kept going and  finished in ninth. Bayliss and 
Haga once again led  the  charge in the  second race, but 
this  time Troy got  his  revenge, beating Nori by 1.353s at 
the  flag. Biaggi was third, some 13  seconds or  so  back, 
with Toseland a  gritty fourth despite a tyre problem. 
Vallelunga was the  event that FGSport had been 
wanting to  stage ever since they took over the  series, 
but  until this  year there was no  reason to  hold a  race 
at what is, at  best, a club circuit. With a certain Max 
Biaggi taking part, though, they finally had  enough

ammunition. How the track was homologated is 
anybody's guess, because there were at least three 
areas which gave cause for concern. When Troy Corser 
asked for some airfencing at the  dangerous exit  of the 
last  turn he was told that it was not  possible because 
the  airfence might intrude onto the  ripple strips. The 
paddock was nowhere big enough for all the  teams, 
so  the  support classes were out  in fields with minimal 
facilities a  long way from the  pits. The Saturday 
afternoon press conference had  to  be cancelled because 
police and  security officials, despite being there in 
huge numbers, could not  or  would not  guarantee the 
safety of the  riders going to  and  from the  pits. It was 
a  logistical nightmare, to  say the  least, but  happily the 
racing, especially on  TV,  was good and  there were no 
accidents or  serious injuries. As  more than one rider said 
afterwards, though, ‘We were lucky today. 
Of course the  fairytale would not  have been 
complete without a  Biaggi win  and  fortunately, for 
the  massive crowd present, he duly obliged in Race 
1, overtaking Bayliss after three laps and  then never 
headed on  his way to  an  historic victory. Toseland was 
third, ahead of Haga. Throughout the  season Biaggi 
had  shown, more than any  other rider, that he was 
the  smoothest racer out  there, best able to conserve 
his tyres and  still  run  fast  at the  end  of a  race. He 
obviously wanted to  do the  double, but  Bayliss spoiled 
the  Roman’s party. Troy led  most of the  race, apart from 
a six-lap stint by Haga, but  was back in control, with 
Biaggi second, with five  laps to  go.  Then Max made a 
mistake and  ran  wide, allowing Bayliss just the  breathing 
space he  needed to  ease away and  take the  chequered 
flag. Biaggi was 1.431s behind at the  finish line, with 
Haga third and  Corser fourth. Toseland crashed at the 
very slow hairpin but  once again remounted to  take 11th 
place, but  his  lead over second-placed Biaggi was down 
to  29  points, with Haga just four points further back. 
Now both Toseland’s pursuers were scenting blood. 
The  odds were still  stacked heavily in James 
Toseland’s favour when the  teams arrived for the  final 
showdown at  Magny-Cours, and normally a  29-point 
advantage would seem pretty good, but  an  incident 
on  the  opening lap of the first race nearly changed 
everything. Lanzi’s fall  at Turn 1 almost caused James 
to  crash. He  managed to stay onboard his  Honda, but 
avoiding the  crash dropped him  way down the  order 
and  suddenly, for  Haga and Biaggi, there was light and 
possible glory at the  end  of the  tunnel. Toseland finished 
seventh, with Haga the  biggest benefactor thanks to 
his win. Biaggi was sixth —  not  out  of contention, but 
knowing now that only a win  and poor results from 
the  other two would give him  the  title. The  final race 
was a tense and  nervy affair, which Haga duly won, but 
Toseland’s sixth place was enough to give him  the  title 
by just two points. It was a fitting send-off to  a  rider 
who has  graced the  World Superbike Championship 
since 2001 and will  ply his trade in MotoGP in 2008. 
Afterwards he said, ‘It’s  hard to  believe that I've 
been in this  championship for seven years. | have really 
enjoyed racing against the  likes of Bayliss, Haga, Biaggi, 
Corser and  the  rest  of the  guys and  am  proud to  have 
beaten them and  taken the  title. The  trophy | won in 
2004 has  been sitting on  the  shelf and getting a  bit 
lonely, so  | thought I'd  better get  it some company. | 
knew that I'd  be going to  MotoGPs three races before 
the  end  of the  season, but  | was determined to  leave as 
a  champion —  for  myself, my family, the Ten  Kate team 
and  everybody who has  helped and  supported me.’ 
Toseland has  been dealt more than his fair  share of 
hard knocks in life,  but  every time he  has  bounced back 
more strongly. His  title win in 2004 was a testament to 
his determination to overcome all odds, and  if anything 
2007 was a  much harder task, but  one  that he once 
again accomplished though his strength, resilience 
and  consistency —  a truly worthy champion for World 
Superbike’s 20th year.

it

pleasing to  see  the  ‘20  years’ on  the  subtitle 
of this  book. So  I’d  like  to  thank the  man 
who 
started 
it 
all, 
Steve 
McLaughlin, 
and 
the 
men who picked up  the  ball  and ran  with it, 
Maurizio and Paolo Flammini, for their faith 
in Superbike. 
Motorcycle racing should be fun  and 
thankfully the  people involved in the  World 
Superbike Championship have always 
remembered that. This has  never stopped 
them from competing at the  highest level 
however. 
Thanks also to  the  Haynes team of Mark 
Hughes and  Flora Myer and  Lee  Parsons, and 
to  Kay  Edge for  her  eagle-eyed subbing. 
Finally, | must say  thanks to  my  wife 
Wendy who has  had  to  put  up  with my 
regular excursions to  race tracks and other 
strange motorcycle-connected behaviour. 
JULIAN RYDER 
Cheshire, 2008 
would 
like  
to 
thank 
my  
wife 
Kay 
for 
all 
her 
tremendous support and understanding 
throughout the  20  years of the  World 
Superbike Championship, particularly all  her 
hard work and  the  hours spent editing this 
edition of the  book, but  especially for  putting 
up with my  frequent excursions. She  was one 
of the  few  people who didn’t think | was mad 
to  leave the  Grand Prix  scene in  1988 for the 
unknown joys of World Superbikes —  though 
| bet  even she  didn’t think that I'd still  be 
involved in it two decades later! 
Warmest thanks to  all at  Haynes, but 
especially to  Carole Bohanan who designed 
this  wonderful new edition of the  book. 
| would also like  to thank all the  riders, 
mechanics and  team personnel who have 
made the  Superbike scene a  great place 
to work and  a  good place to  have a  party. 
Many a  Sunday night has  been spent in 
their company and many have become good 
friends, particularly Fred Merkel —  the  first 
champion. He  was a  great ambassador for the 
series when it started, and  quickly became a 
travelling companion and  friend of the  family. 
In latter years many an  enjoyable evening 
has  been spent in the  company of Scott 
Russell, Troy Corser and  James Toseland; 
all race hard and  know how to  have fun 
afterwards. 
Thanks 
also 
to 
Francis 
and 
Patricia 
Batta for  employing this  freelancer ten  years 
ago 
and 
making 
sure 
he 
was 
well 
fed 
and 
watered in their hospitality unit. 
When the  championship first  started, there 
were 
only 
small 
trucks 
and 
hardly 
any 
catering, 
but 
now 
that 
World 
Superbikes 
is 
a 
global 
phenomenon that has  changed to  packed 
paddocks 
of 
semi-trailers 
and 
lavish 
hospitality 
units. What has  not  changed from those 
early days, though, is the  warm and  friendly 
atmosphere; on  the  track it’s war, but  off  it 
the 
riders, 
mechanics 
and 
press 
all 
mix 
freely 
and manage to  have fun. 
| am  happy to  have joined the World 
Superbike Championship right at the  very 
beginning and I’m  even happier to  be still 
involved with it today. 
KEL EDGE 
London, 2008
